sense.def: a large tree found in northern countries, or the wood of this tree
dictionaryExamples: an oak table
The floors are solid oak.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a very old oak [in the] middle of the garden. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: extremely fat
dictionaryExamples: Currently, 15% of the population are classified as obese.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Less physical activity and [a] poor diet can lead to being overweight or even obese. International English Language Testing System; C1; Farsi

sense.def: the state of being extremely fat
dictionaryExamples: The government is concerned about childhood obesity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many researchers say that obesity and other adult diseases are getting common as we eat more western food. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: to do what you are told to do by a person, rule, or instruction
dictionaryExamples: The soldiers refused to obey (orders).
They must obey the rules of international law.
People failing to obey the law will be fined.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have strict parents who tell me what to do and what not to do every day. If I don't obey them, I'll be punished for sure. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a thing that you can see or touch but that is usually not alive
dictionaryExamples: a bright, shiny object
There were various objects on display.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I saw [many] things like dinosaur bones, mummies, va[r]ious objects, etc. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: in grammar, the person or thing that is affected by the action of the verb or the person or thing that comes after a preposition
dictionaryExamples: In the sentence "I like ice cream," "ice cream" is the object of the verb "like."

sense.def: the purpose of something
dictionaryExamples: The object of this game is to score more points than the opposing team.
The object of the exercise is to complete the task within the time limit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In extreme cases, famous people are the object of the rage and hate many people bury in themselves. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to feel or say that you do not like or do not approve of something or someone
dictionaryExamples: He objects to the label "magician," which he is often called.
Would anyone object if we started the meeting now?
No one objected when the boss said it was time to go home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to object to what the reporter said in his conclusion. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: when someone says that they do not like or approve of something or someone
dictionaryExamples: Our main objection to the restaurant adding outdoor tables is that it will be noisy.
I have no objection if you want to stay an extra day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion there are two main objections to the existence of zoos. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: something that you are trying to achieve
dictionaryExamples: Her main/prime objective now is simply to stay in office.
Can the company achieve/meet its financial objectives?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you think I [will] have [the right] conditions to do the [diving] course and achieve my objectives? First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: only influenced by facts and not by feelings
dictionaryExamples: I try to be objective when I review someone's work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Friends can be more objective concerning your faults and can give you [a] different point of view. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: in a way that is only influenced by facts and not by feelings
dictionaryExamples: This test assesses all candidates objectively.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The articles are objectively written and what is more they are comprehensible to the majority of people. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: something that you do because it is your duty or because you feel you have to
dictionaryExamples: If you have not signed a contract, you are under no obligation to  pay them any money.
You have a legal obligation to  ensure your child receives a proper education.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: In spite of all these activities and obligations you don't have to worry about your rest because you will work just 5 hours a day and you will have enough free time to play your guitar. 
 First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: required, usually by a rule or law
dictionaryExamples: The street was lined with the obligatory blue bins used for recyclable trash.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think this is a very good way of encouraging people to learn to like exercise without them having to do it because it is obligatory. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: expected because it is usual
dictionaryExamples: When we were in England, we made the obligatory trip to Stonehenge.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everybody should try a Danish lunch with the obligatory bread with her[r]ing and lots of beer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: much too large or much more than is needed or necessary
dictionaryExamples: obscene profits
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Needless to say, the price was 'obscene', but I did not care. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def:
offensive, rude, or disgusting
 according to accepted moral standards, often relating to sex in a way that is unpleasant or shocking
dictionaryExamples: an obscene gesture
obscene language
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a woman with [a] deep, sexual voice, talking about my boyfriend with obscene innuendos about our relationship. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: good or quick at noticing things
dictionaryExamples: He's very observant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What's more, Len is the most patient and observant listener I have ever come across. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: when someone watches someone or something carefully
dictionaryExamples: The doctor wants to keep him under observation for a week.
She has very good powers of observation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But actually it is boring when you're almost always under observation. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a remark about something that you have noticed
dictionaryExamples: He made an interesting observation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to make some observations regarding your CDs. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: to watch someone or something carefully
dictionaryExamples: The role of scientists is to observe and describe the world, not to try to control it.
He spent a year in the jungle, observing how deforestation is affecting local peoples.
Children learn by observing adults.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To support [the] idea [of] mak[ing] a short video about daily life at our school I have spen[t] some time discussing it with other students, observing and anal[y]sing an av[era]ge day in our school. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to notice something
dictionaryExamples: Jack observed a look of anxiety on his brother's face.
The guards failed to observe who delivered the package.
In all these films one observes that directors are taking a new interest in Native American culture.
Differences in speech styles may be observed between other social groups.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Two trends can be observed: one, "sociological", giving women [a] more and more important role in our country, and the other, "cultural", still keeping them to three "sacred things" - household, kids and [the] church. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Latvian

sense.def: to obey a law, rule, or religious custom
dictionaryExamples: to observe the law

sense.def: a person who watches what happens but has no active part in it
dictionaryExamples: Political observers are expecting the election result to be close.
UN observers are monitoring the ceasefire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not even UN observers from other African countries understood this. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: something or someone that you think about all the time
dictionaryExamples: an unhealthy obsession with death
her chocolate obsession
He's always wanted to find his natural mother but recently it's become an obsession.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Shopping is an obsession for all of us. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: thinking too much about something, or doing something too much
dictionaryExamples: obsessive behavior
He's obsessive about his health.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first I followed in an extremely obsessive way the swimming competitions, which lasted almost a week. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: not used now
dictionaryExamples: obsolete equipment
Will books become obsolete because of computers?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The museum's advertisement promises an exciting experience, so students were surprised to find [so] many obsolete machines of no interest. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: something that makes it difficult for you to do something or to succeed at something
dictionaryExamples: to overcome an obstacle
His refusal to talk is the main obstacle to peace.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Another obstacle for those students who wish to study in the library after classes, is the totally devastating fact of early closure. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a thing that blocks your way and is difficult to go around
dictionaryExamples: We suddenly encountered an obstacle along the trail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They had many obstacles in their way, for example a wall of bricks and no ladder to help them get on the other side - some of them were helping each other  and could continue this rat race, and some had to finish it then. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to get something
dictionaryExamples: to obtain information
First editions of these books are now almost impossible to obtain.
Under the new law, everyone will be required to obtain health insurance.
The documents and e-mails were obtained by the local newspaper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now, he has obtained [a] permit from other countries to plant sugar in their countries. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: easy to understand or see
dictionaryExamples: "How do you know she's not happy?" "It's obvious."
It's obvious (that) she doesn't like him.
There is no obvious solution.
They have a small child so for obvious reasons they need money.
I know you don't like her, but do you have to make it so obvious?
Am I just stating the obvious?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The answers [to] your questions are obvious. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: in a way that is easy to understand or see
dictionaryExamples: Obviously, the school cannot function without teachers.
He was in tears and obviously very upset.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Obviously it's a special day for all the family, so we spend a lot of time - and also lots of money - [o]n dresses, food and flowers. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: an important event or ceremony
dictionaryExamples: a special occasion
At the wedding, he sang a song written just for the occasion.
I have a suit but I only wear it on special occasions.
Congratulations on the occasion of your 25th wedding anniversary.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I enjoy wearing clothes for special occasions - for example [a] nice long dress. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: a time when something happens
dictionaryExamples: That was a different/another occasion.
We met on several occasions to discuss the issue.
He's missed meetings on a number of occasions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On one occasion our teacher left the class. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: sometimes, but not often
dictionaryExamples: He has, on occasion, told a small lie.

sense.def: not happening or done often or regularly
dictionaryExamples: occasional snowstorms
His job requires occasional trips to the West Coast.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is only occasional, but you have to plan ahead about when you are going to have a bath or shower and heat the water up. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: sometimes but not often
dictionaryExamples: We occasionally get together for dinner.
I'll occasionally have some chocolate, but not much.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will need to use the computer to contact my friend on E-Mail and occasionally listen to a couple of CDs. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: your job
dictionaryExamples: You have to give your name, age and occupation on the application form.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the first lesson we introduced ourselves and described our occupation, interests and so on, to each other. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: something that you do in your free time
dictionaryExamples: He has a few occupations, such as gardening and woodwork.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She made literature classes an engaging activity and fun and turned reading into an absorbing and fascinating occupation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: when an army moves into a place and takes control of it
dictionaryExamples: a military occupation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During the German occupation in Greece she was alone in Athens with her two children, because her husband had died in Albania, fighting against the Italians. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to fill or use a place or period of time
dictionaryExamples: His book collection occupies most of the room.
All the seats were occupied.
The babies seem to occupy all our time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An intelligent solution to this is the bicycle, which can be parked almost everywhere and occupies little space. First Certificate in English; B2; Slovene

sense.def: to keep someone busy or interested
dictionaryExamples: On long car trips I occupy myself with puzzles.
The new video game kept the kids occupied for hours.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So in order to keep myself occupied for a while, I went to the restaurant, except it wasn't open. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to move into a place and take control of it
dictionaryExamples: The troops eventually occupied most of the island.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a show called "Taxa" based on true stor[ies]. It takes you back to 1942, when Denmark was occupied by Germany. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: to happen, often without being planned
dictionaryExamples: The accident occurred at 10:15 in the east-bound lane and traffic was tied up for three hours.
Flooding occurred in low-lying areas as  a result of heavy rains.
If any of these symptoms occur, call your doctor immediately.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, I think that most accidents that occur with cars are due to the irrespons[i]bility of some drivers and I think strong measures should be taken in order to punish them. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: an event or something that happens
dictionaryExamples: a common/rare occurrence
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many people would think this is [a] normal occurrence and take this capacity for granted, but my experience has been that this is not the case and that there are many people out there, especially parents, unable to show their true feelings. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the existence or presence of something
dictionaryExamples: The tests can detect the occurrence of certain cancers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Its line shows the occurrence of two peaks: one in the early 1980's (14%) and another one is expected to happen in the year 2010. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: a very large area of salt water
dictionaryExamples: the Atlantic/Pacific/Indian/Arctic/Antarctic Ocean
to swim in the ocean
These mysterious creatures live at the bottom of the ocean.
We rented a house by the ocean for a two-week vacation.
We're going on an ocean cruise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My favorite room is the first to the right because I like the color and because [from] the window, I can see the ocean. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a very small amount compared to the amount needed
dictionaryExamples: My letter of protest was just a drop in the ocean.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know I am a drop in the ocean, but I'm convinced it's the only way, my way, of contributing to improve education in Mexico. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the tenth month of the year, after September and before November
dictionaryExamples: the 22nd of October/October 22nd
We're leaving for Italy on October ninth/the ninth of October.
Sara's birthday is some time in October.
It's been the wettest October for years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think the class start[s] the 3rd of October and finishe[s] the 16th. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: strange or unusual
dictionaryExamples: Her father was an odd man.
What an odd thing to say.
It struck me as odd that he didn't call.
That's odd  - I'm sure I put my keys in this drawer, but they're not here.
It's a odd that no one has seen him all day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That struck me as odd, since [i]t had never happened before. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to talk about something that happens or exists sometimes but not often
dictionaryExamples: She does the odd teaching job but nothing permanent.
You get the odd person who's rude to you but they're generally quite helpful.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This attitude makes it difficult for the odd foreigner who tries to get involved with the local community. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: in a strange or surprising way
dictionaryExamples: an oddly shaped house
Oddly enough, despite the sizzling heat, scientists suspect there could be water frozen on Mercury.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Oddly enough, she never seems to be really angry and perhaps it is the reason why I like confiding in her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the probability that a particular thing will or will not happen
dictionaryExamples: She was sick yesterday, so the odds are she won’t be in today.
What are the odds on him being  reelected?
The odds are stacked against a woman succeeding  in this business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After all, on the battlefield for promotion, men still have a vital interest to set the odds against women in favor of their own opportunities. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: If you do or achieve something against all the odds, you succeed although you were not likely to.
dictionaryExamples: We won the game against all odds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The stormy waters and heavy winds were a great challenge, and almost deemed it impossible for me to succeed, but against all odds I managed to defeat my fears. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: various items of different types that are not valuable or important
dictionaryExamples: We moved most of the furniture to the new house, but there are still a few odds and ends to bring over.
I keep odds and ends in that  box.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The photograph spent some time there; in the drawer under [the] odds and ends everybody has. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to not agree with someone or something
dictionaryExamples: The two brothers were always at odds.
His remark was at odds with our report.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Young people are inexperienced as far as the world is concerned and thus they are frequently at odds with their family. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a particular smell, often one that is  unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: the musty odor of a damp cellar
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even though all the lights were on an[d] there was an unpleasant odor of recently put-out cigarettes and also a smell of an expensive perfume, he just couldn't get a glimpse of anyone. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: belonging or relating to someone or something
dictionaryExamples: a friend of mine
the color of her hair
part of the problem
employees of the company
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The name of my friend is Maria. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic

sense.def: used after words that show an amount
dictionaryExamples: a pound of potatoes
loads of food
hundreds of people
most of them
none of them
both of us
a third of all people
a drop of rain
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She has a lot of flowers in her room. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: containing
dictionaryExamples: a bag of popcorn
a bottle of water
a book of short stories
bags of groceries
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like cups of tea, I like noodles, but I don't like beef. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Mandarin

sense.def: used with numbers, ages and dates
dictionaryExamples: an essay of 500 words
a boy of six
the 14th of February 2005
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The class started [on] the 2nd of June at half past five. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to say "yes" and emphasize your answer
dictionaryExamples: "Can you help me?" "Of course!"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yes of course I can come. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used in expressions showing position
dictionaryExamples: the top of his head
the back of your dress
on the corner of the street
the front of the line
They live in a suburb west of Toronto.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First you [go] pas[t] [a] big supermarket on the corner of my street. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: showing someone or something
dictionaryExamples: a map of downtown
a photo of my family
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tony gave me a photo of Henry. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: used when comparing related things
dictionaryExamples: Worst of all was the food!
He's the oldest of the three brothers.
I think that of all his films, this one is my favorite.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The best of all was a necklace. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: used to say "no" and emphasize your answer
dictionaryExamples: "Do you mind if I borrow your pen?" "Of course not."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Pardon. You said your [u]ncle's will? Would you mind explaining [that], please?" "Of course not!" First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: used to show who or what does something
dictionaryExamples: the works of Shakespeare
the arrival of the rainy season
the music of Spain
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They often cover the music of "The Beatles" or "The Rolling Stones". Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: showing a reason or cause
dictionaryExamples: He died of cancer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But, three months later, after walk[ing] in the rain he died of pneumonia. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to show that what you are saying is obvious or already known
dictionaryExamples: Of course, the Olympics are not just about money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, I met many new people. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: used after an adjective when judging someone's behavior
dictionaryExamples: It was very nice of you to think of us.
It was a bit mean of him to say that!
Thank you so much for my present. How thoughtful of you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was most thoughtful of you to invite us and I warmly appreciate your hospitality. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: about or relating to
dictionaryExamples: Speaking of Elizabeth, here she is.
Let us consider the events of the last five months.
We  know very little of her childhood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Speaking of sightseeing, many thought that visiting other sights - like the Folk Museum - should not be compulsory. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: used to say "before" the hour when you are saying what time it is
dictionaryExamples: It's ten of five.

sense.def: not important
dictionaryExamples: The money was of little consequence to Tony.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Second, the downpour of rain which was mentioned was in fact nothing more than a small shower, of no significant consequence for the dance display and horse show. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: If you do something of your own accord, you choose to do it and no one else forces you.
dictionaryExamples: She left of her own accord.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She would go alone, but it was something that was chosen of her own accord. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: not at work
dictionaryExamples: I had six weeks off when my son was born.
I'm going to take some time off to work on my house.
She was off last week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will take a day off on Friday. Key English Test; A2; Czech

sense.def: used with actions in which something is removed or removes itself from another thing
dictionaryExamples: Take your jacket off.
One of my buttons came off.
She had all her hair cut off.
I left the lid off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I took off my ring. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: not operating or being used
dictionaryExamples: Make sure the computers are turned off before you go home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When we arrived home, all the lights were off and everything was peaceful. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: away from a place or position
dictionaryExamples: I'm off to the grocery store.
Keep the dog on the leash or he'll just run off.
Keep off the grass.
"Is Kara still here?" "You missed her - she just drove off."
She's off to Canada next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They g[o]t into the car and drove off. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Slovak

sense.def: If a price has a certain amount of money off, it costs that much less than the usual price.
dictionaryExamples: You can get some money off if you pay cash.
There's 40% off this week on all winter coats.
There was $40 or $50 off most jackets in the store.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He promised me 30% off the price, so I'm going to buy the TV and the CD player from him. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish

sense.def: far in distance or time
dictionaryExamples: You can see the city off in the distance.
My vacation seems a long way off.
The wedding is so far off, I'm not even thinking about it yet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Allow me to start by saying that one day, which may l[ie] not so far off in the future, people will visit the buildings which were formerly known as "Educational Institutions" like we visit museums to gape at the sheer size of the Dinosaurs... Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: down or away from a place or position
dictionaryExamples: All the leaves had dropped off the tree.
He fell off his bike.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I still remember the way your brother fell off the lad[d]er that day. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: used with actions in which something is removed or removes itself from another thing
dictionaryExamples: I can't get the lid off this jar.
Has anyone taken a book off my desk?
Could you cut me a small piece off that white cheese?
Take your feet off the seat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Next month, I'm going to change my bedroom. I'll take the photographs off the wall. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: near to a building or place
dictionaryExamples: an island off the coast of Spain
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He spent all night off the coast, (unfinished) First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: If someone such as a doctor or a soldier is off duty, they are not working.
dictionaryExamples: What time do you go off duty tomorrow?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes I come off duty at ten p.m. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: in a place where few people go
dictionaryExamples: I prefer to take my vacation somewhere off the beaten track.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, in areas off the beaten track, there [are] not even police sometimes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If food or drink is off, it is not now fresh and good to eat or drink.
dictionaryExamples: This milk smells off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Who knows if the food isn't off? First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: stopped or given up
dictionaryExamples: Last night’s baseball game was called off because of rain.
We didn't get the funding for the show, so it's off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On that day, she had written him a big long letter and told him that it was all off, for she didn't love him any longer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make someone upset or angry
dictionaryExamples: I think she was a bit offended that she hadn't been invited to the party.
He looked a offended when you called him middle-aged.
If the sight of a few dirty dishes offends you, then I think you've got problems!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know that she was not offended but I will never forget my stupid question. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: someone who has committed a crime
dictionaryExamples: first-time/repeat offenders
violent offenders
juvenile/young/youthful offenders
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The ticket fare is very reasonable, [and] there [are] always police p[a]tro[l]ling around, protecting the people from offenders. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: in sports such as football, the part of a team which tries to score points
dictionaryExamples: The offense been having trouble moving the ball down the field.

sense.def: a crime
dictionaryExamples: Driving without a license is an offense.
a serious/minor offense
a criminal offense
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, using a bike [keeps] you free of any parking problem [or] parking offen[s]e and your bike will wait [for] you all day long, [because] it won't be to[w]ed-away! First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: when something rude makes someone upset or angry
dictionaryExamples: Do you think he took offense  at what I said about his hair?
If you don't mind, I'd rather go on my own - no offense, but I think it would be better.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you will not take offen[s]e but I think you work too much. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: likely to make people angry or upset
dictionaryExamples: This program contains language that some viewers might find offensive.
I thought some of his comments were offensive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Sir/Madam, The review on the Westfield Music Festival was both offensive and incorrect. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to say that you are willing to do something
dictionaryExamples: Paul has offered to help us pack.
"I'll do the cooking," he offered.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Robbie, Thank you for offering to help me paint my bedroom. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to ask someone if they would like something
dictionaryExamples: They've offered me a job.
Can I offer you  a drink?
I feel bad that I didn't offer them something to eat.
Someone should offer that man a seat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He offered me a contract and asked me to go to his music studio to record a CD. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: to give or provide something
dictionaryExamples: to offer advice
We are now offering you the chance/opportunity to buy the complete set of DVDs at half price.
Did he offer any explanation for his strange behavior?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Rome offers good nightlife so after visiting [the] museum, we'll be able to go to [the] disco. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to say that you will pay a particular amount of money
dictionaryExamples: I offered him $1200 for the car.
Police have offered a $1,000 reward for information.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My company will offer 20 percent more than the minimum wage that exists for the same type of work in Canada. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: when you ask someone if they would like something
dictionaryExamples: an offer  of help
a job offer
to accept/refuse an offer
"Can I pick anything up for you from the store?" "It's kind or you to offer."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you very much for your offer.  Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: a cheap price or special arrangement for something you are buying
dictionaryExamples: This special offer ends on Friday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We found a £12 offer to Leeds Castle including bus transfer and entrance ticket for the castle. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: an amount of money that you say you will pay for something
dictionaryExamples: The highest offer anyone has made so far is $500.

sense.def: a room or building where people work
dictionaryExamples: I didn't leave the office until eight o'clock last night.
the manager's office
an office building
office staff
office equipment
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's better for me to meet [at] central park, nex[t] to my office. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: the place where a doctor or other medical person sees patients
dictionaryExamples: the doctor's/dentist's office
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need to change the hour of our meeting next Tuesday because I have an appointment [at] the doctor's office at 4:00 o'clock. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a room or building where you can get information, tickets, or a particular service
dictionaryExamples: a ticket office
the passport office
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suggest [we] meet at 4:50 p.m, in the ticket office. Preliminary English Test; B1; Bengali

sense.def: an important job in a government or other organization
dictionaryExamples: the office of executive vice president
County judge is an elective office.
Some people think he has been in office for too long.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The former Polish prime minister was a woman - Hanna Suchocka - and she was able to remain in office for 15 months, in the time when the life expectancy of governments in Poland is about half a year. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Latvian

sense.def: a police officer
dictionaryExamples: a uniformed officer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They sent me an officer: Officer McDonald, from the anti-mafia department. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a person who has a position of authority in an organization
dictionaryExamples: I had an interview with the university admissions officer.
the chief executive/financial officer
a customs/corrections officer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I work as [a] customs officer and [in] this job I meet a lot of foreign people every day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: someone with an important job in a military organization
dictionaryExamples: a military officer
an army/navy officer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was an officer in [the] army. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: approved by the government or someone in authority
dictionaryExamples: the official language of Singapore
an official document
There will be an official investigation into the incident.
We were invited to the official opening of the exhibit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have worked as an official translator in [the] British Embass[y] in Seoul. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: connected with or arranged by someone in a position of responsibility
dictionaryExamples: an official visit
An official announcement is expected this afternoon.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: For exactly that reason official reports are issued by doctors or psychologists in court in order to check the person's mental health and respons[i]bility for the crime. 
 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: known by the public
dictionaryExamples: Their engagement is now official.
Inflation has fallen below 2%, and that's official.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was now official, she was the most beautiful girl of the school. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: An official explanation or statement is one that is given, but which may not be true.
dictionaryExamples: The official reason for the delay is bad weather.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, this was the official reason to explain his stay, [but] the truth - which I had learned later - was that Martin was a broken man. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a person who has a position of responsibility in a government or organization
dictionaryExamples: a UN official
a senior official
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As to city officials, if they manage the whole event fine, this feat is bound to boost their chances at the next elections. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian

sense.def: formally and in a way agreed to or arranged by people in positions of authority
dictionaryExamples: The new store was officially opened yesterday.
The name of the new director will be officially announced in June.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I could travel back to any place and time in history, I would choose the day when Wor[l]d War II was officially declared over. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: slightly unpleasant or worrying so that you do not want to get involved in any way
dictionaryExamples: He's slightly aggressive, which a lot of people find a bit off-putting when they first meet him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, it's quite off-putting to stay in Hong Kong for higher education. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: If one thing offsets another thing, it has the opposite effect and so creates a more balanced situation.
dictionaryExamples: The costs have been offset by savings in other areas.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During the interview, she tried to offset the bad impression she was sure she had made. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the child of a person or animal
dictionaryExamples: to produce offspring
Champion horses have numerous offspring.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is vital that parents be around their offspring, especially when they are young, to establish a warm, trusting relationship. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: many times or regularly
dictionaryExamples: I often shop there.
I often have a glass of milk before bed.
How often do you wash your hair?
I don't see him very often.
It's not often you meet someone who you immediately like.
I don't see my parents as often as I'd like to.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We often [go] swimming together. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: If something often happens or is often true, it is normal for it to happen, or it is usually true.
dictionaryExamples: Brothers and sisters often argue.
Headaches are often caused by stress.
It often rains in April.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Very often, people link classical music to Austrian or German [composers], [such] as Mozart or Handel, but rarely to England and genius[es] [such] as Haydn and Purcell. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: sometimes, but not often
dictionaryExamples: He went into town every so often to buy supplies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And likewise, common sense tells us it doesn't matter that oranges from Spain contain 0.01% more vitamin C than those from Florid[a], as long as we eat them every once in a while. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: introduces an idea that you have just thought of, or something that you have just remembered
dictionaryExamples: Oh, I just realized there might be a problem.
Oh, and don't forget to lock the back door.
Oh yeah, someone called and left a message for you while you were out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Oh, and don't forget to show up in old clothes, ok? Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to express different emotions, such as surprise, disappointment and pleasure, often as a reaction to something someone has said
dictionaryExamples: "Jack can't come after all." "Oh too bad, Amy will be sorry to hear that."
"He ran the Boston marathon last year." "Oh, really? I didn't know that!"
"I'm afraid I can't make it to the party." " Oh well, maybe next time."
Is that for me? Oh, that's so nice of you!
"I'm sorry I forgot to call." "Oh, don't worry."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Oh, that's ok. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to emphasize how surprised, angry, shocked, etc. you are
dictionaryExamples: Oh my gosh, I'm so happy to see you! When did you get here?

sense.def: a thick liquid produced from plants  that is used in cooking
dictionaryExamples: olive/sunflower/vegetable oil
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi Fatima, I think you can bring some potatoes, olive oil and lettuce. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: a thick liquid that comes from under the Earth's surface that is used as a fuel and for making parts of machines move easily
dictionaryExamples: an oil company
engine oil
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is working in a big oil company called Agip. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to work late into the night
dictionaryExamples: I had to burn the midnight oil to get the essay finished.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My examinations were nearing and I was always burning the midnight oil. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: used when agreeing to do something or when allowing someone to do something
dictionaryExamples: "Could you pick me up at the train station?" "OK, what time?"
"I'll pay you back tomorrow." "OK, no problem."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: OK. See you for dinner! Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used to check that someone understands something or that they agree to something
dictionaryExamples: So I'll get the food and you can get the drink, OK?
I'll see you at six-thirty, okay?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't forget to wear [an] old shirt and jeans, okay? Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used as a way of showing that you are going to take action, start speaking or start something new
dictionaryExamples: OK then, if you're ready we'll get started.
Okay, let's go.

sense.def: not sick, damaged, upset, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Are you OK? You look pale.
How's Paola? Is she okay after her fall yesterday?
"Is everything OK with you?" "Yes, fine."
I'll just check that the car's okay - that was a big bang!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi, Ramesh, What are you doing? Are you OK? Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Spanish

sense.def: good or good enough
dictionaryExamples: Is your food OK?
"Did you have a nice dinner out last night?" "It was OK."
Her voice is OK, but nothing special.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, about the music, I think salsa and rock music [are] OK. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: allowed or acceptable
dictionaryExamples: Is it OK if I bring a friend to the party?
Is it okay to eat in here?
If it's okay with you, I'll leave the grocery shopping till tomorrow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Ally, It's okay that you couldn't come. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: in a satisfactory way
dictionaryExamples: Everything was going OK until the printer stopped working.
Did you sleep okay?
I just called to make sure that you got home okay.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally the day finished OK. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: having lived or existed for many years
dictionaryExamples: an old man
an old house
We're all getting older.
I was shocked by how old he looked.
I'm too old to be out dancing every night.
That's an old joke - I've heard it about a thousand times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Wroctaw is [an] old town. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used to describe or ask about someone's age
dictionaryExamples: How old is your father?
Rosie's six years old now.
He's a couple of years older than me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is 23 years old. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German

sense.def: from a period in the past
dictionaryExamples: I saw my old English teacher last time I went home.
He bought me a fancy new camera to replace my old one.
She showed me her old school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My old one is [a] Nokia. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: someone who you have known and liked for a long time
dictionaryExamples: I saw an old friend who I went to high school with.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you remember my old friend Jack? Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: a period in the past
dictionaryExamples: This place isn't as good as it was in the old days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the old days, a scholar could spend years of his life in search of specific information, which now can be easily and inexpensi[ve]ly found at the click of a button! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: not modern
dictionaryExamples: old-fashioned clothes/ideas/furniture
She's pretty old-fashioned about some things.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But I don't like clothes with stripes, because I think that's a little old-fashioned. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: a small green or black fruit with a bitter taste that is eaten or used to produce oil
dictionaryExamples: olive oil
olive trees
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In [the] countryside there are some hills, some sunflowers, olive trees and many medieval town[s]  on the hills to visit! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: eggs that have been mixed and fried, often with other foods added
dictionaryExamples: a cheese/mushroom omelet

sense.def: when something has not been included that should have been
dictionaryExamples: Parents are upset by the omission of music from the school’s courses.
There are some serious errors and omissions in this book.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, I think it would be an omission if I didn't mention the children that live in poverty and die from starvation and diseases every day.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to not include something
dictionaryExamples: I’d be upset if my name were omitted from the list of contributors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, [an] important aspect of language learning is good access to books and other written materials.  For this reason, you should not omit our recently moderni[z]ed library. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: on or onto a surface
dictionaryExamples: Ouch! You stepped on my foot.
I dropped my pen on the floor.
Look at all the books on your desk!
We put any medicines on a high shelf.
Your suitcase is on a shelf in the closet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can read the book, listen to music, watch TV or just sit on my sofa and drink a hot [cup of] tea. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used to show the day or date when something happens
dictionaryExamples: Some of the stores aren't open on Sundays.
What are you doing on Friday?
My birthday's on the 30th of May.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dinner will be on Friday at 7:00. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: covering, touching, attached to or hanging from something
dictionaryExamples: You've got blood on your shirt.
Which finger do you wear your ring on?
We could hang this picture on the wall next to the door.
Dogs should be kept on a leash at all times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like my bedroom, because there are [a] lot of windows, two armchair[s], a lamp next to the bed, a table under the window, [and] some pictures on the wall. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic

sense.def: used to refer to a place when giving directions
dictionaryExamples: Our house is the first on the left after the post office.
Turn right on Broadway.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My house is the first one on the left. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak

sense.def: used for showing some methods of traveling
dictionaryExamples: He called to say he's on the bus and will be here in a few minutes.
She'll be arriving on the five-thirty train.
We went to France on the ferry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will travel on a train and then I will take [a] taxi to your home. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: in a particular place
dictionaryExamples: the diagram on page 22
They lived on a farm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I live on a farm in the Emmental. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: used to show the way in which something is recorded or broadcast
dictionaryExamples: What's on television tonight?
When's that movie coming out on DVD?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I watched ice hockey on cable TV at night. Key English Test; A2; Czech

sense.def: used to show what money or time is used for
dictionaryExamples: She refuses to spend more than $30 on a pair of shoes.
I've wasted too much time on this already.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I love it and I spend all my time on it. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: walking
dictionaryExamples: Are you going by bicycle or on foot?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It isn't far away from the main building [-] it's about 15 minutes on foot. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: available at a reduced price
dictionaryExamples: I love that dress but I'm waiting until it's on sale before I buy it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I bought a nice t-shirt and a pair of shorts.  I bought them because they're comfortable and cheap: they were on sale. I spent 15€. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: available to buy in stores, on the Internet, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The video and book are now on sale.
Tickets went on sale yesterday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went window shopping with my friends yesterday and I saw this beautiful skirt on sale. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay

sense.def: about
dictionaryExamples: a book on plants
Her thesis is on Italian women's literature.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The other one is a book on dogs and cats. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: next to or along the side of a place or area
dictionaryExamples: New York  is on the Hudson River.
Our house was on Sturton Street.
Strasbourg is on the border of France and Germany.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Remember our meeting is in the Golden Crown, next to the tall building on 67th street. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: using something
dictionaryExamples: I do all my bookkeeping on the computer.
That's Chris on drums and Mike on guitar.
I'm on the phone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was in the pizza shop to order some food for my family and I was on the phone. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Farsi

sense.def: on a boat, train, aircraft, etc.
dictionaryExamples: There were 230 people on board the plane.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was all the more excited as it was the first time I have been on board such a big boat. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: If something is on fire, it is burning when it should not be.
dictionaryExamples: If your home was on fire and you could save only one thing, what would it be?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A lot of bu[i]ldings were on fire. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: intentionally
dictionaryExamples: I didn't do it on purpose, it was an accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't do it on purpose; it was dark and I just walked into it. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: not early or late
dictionaryExamples: I got to school on time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, I will not be on time for my English class tomorrow. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: If something is on display, it is there for people to look at.
dictionaryExamples: Many old airplanes are on display in the museum.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were some new musical instruments on display. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: generally
dictionaryExamples: We've had a few problems, but on the whole we're very happy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the whole I don't like watching television. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: alone
dictionaryExamples: I like living on my own.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On Wedn[e]sday morning I went on my own to see [the] Vatican. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: without any help
dictionaryExamples: Ryan can't get into his shirt on his own - he's just a baby!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe I can do the missing work on my own. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: used to show what happens as a result of touching or hitting against something
dictionaryExamples: You'll cut yourself on that knife if you're not careful.
I hit my head on the shelf as I was standing up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly I hit my head on the bed as the man was talking. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to show something which is used as food or fuel
dictionaryExamples: What do frogs live on?
Does this radio run on batteries?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All new cars run on unleaded fuel w[h]ich is a benefit to the environment. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: on behalf of sb or on sb's behalf

sense.def: If you do something on behalf of someone, you do it for them or instead of them.
dictionaryExamples: On behalf of the entire company, I would like to thank you for all your work.

Unfortunately, George cannot be with us today so I am pleased to accept this award on his
                             behalf.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am writing on behalf of our college English club members to welcome you [to] our city. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: used to give your opinion after you have considered all the facts about something
dictionaryExamples: On balance, I'd rather go straight home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On balance, I think that getting to work by bike offers more advantages than going by car, most of all for traffic and [the] environment. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: only if
dictionaryExamples: I'll go with you on the condition that we get back before midnight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to do this on condition that you will not mention my name [on] the website. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: If someone such as a doctor or a soldier is on duty, they are working.
dictionaryExamples: What time are you on duty tomorrow?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was on duty in front of the major's house with another soldier. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: in addition to something else
dictionaryExamples: He tripped and hurt his back, and on top of that, he lost his cell phone.
And then, on top of everything else, her car was stolen!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I turned around, I saw that it [had] rained in almost every part of the room and on top of that, there were some bab[y] wolves with their mother, sleeping on the bed. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: on the one hand . . . on the other hand

sense.def: used when you are comparing two different ideas or opinions
dictionaryExamples: On the one hand, computer games develop many skills, but on the other, they mean kids don't get enough exercise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the one hand, I know from my experience that it's much easier in life if you know more about everything, but on the other hand, I'd say that if someone [had given] me a chance (when I was kid) to study what I enjoy[ed],  probably I'd have more possibility to develop my skills. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to be a member of a group or organization
dictionaryExamples: She's on the refreshments committee.
How many people are on your staff?
There are 14 people on the Board of Trustees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I am the student represen[ta]tive on the committee, I would like to suggest some ideas. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: played on television or radio
dictionaryExamples: His show is on the air from 11:00 to 11:30 Monday through Thursday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you can see, it’s probably the first chance to learn good English on T.V. Another surprising thing is that it's not on the air too late, so you can watch it without oversleeping in the morning. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to be quick to understand and react to things
dictionaryExamples: She's over ninety, but she's still on the ball.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you're at Sants station, you'll need to be on the ball. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: as the result of something
dictionaryExamples: Grades are awarded  on the basis of progress and performance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the basis of the points mentioned above, it is a foregone conclusion that young people do not face any severe problems. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: because of a particular reason
dictionaryExamples: You cannot discriminate on the grounds of religion.
I  refused  on the grounds that it was too risky.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am convinced that it is better than Southside College on the grounds that a great mass of students are satisfied. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: If a plan or activity is on hold, it will not be done until a later time.
dictionaryExamples: The project is on hold until we raise more money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What's more, it might, intentional[l]y or not, raise awareness on issues that might have been put on hold by authorities, such as the legalization of soft drugs. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: waiting to speak to someone on the telephone
dictionaryExamples: His secretary put me on hold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The day after, I called your office and after being put on hold, the person answering the phone was unwilling to come up with a proper reply. International English Language Testing System; C1; Dutch

sense.def: likely to happen soon
dictionaryExamples: Economic recovery is on the horizon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Often this is justified as [a] result of society being collective[ly] afraid that a shortage of fuel is on the horizon. International English Language Testing System; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: If something is on the increase, it is happening more often.
dictionaryExamples:
Homelessness is on the increase in many
 cities.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] number of motorists is on the increase everywhere in the world. International English Language Testing System; C1; Czech

sense.def: at the place where you work, or while you work
dictionaryExamples: She's only had two years on the job and has been promoted already.
He keeps falling asleep on the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not managing on the job wouldn't just have been your failure, but also [your] employer's, who had trusted you. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: If something is on loan, someone is borrowing it.
dictionaryExamples: Both paintings are on loan from the city museum.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, you can always take out on loan any video you like from our center. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: If a film or television program is made on location, it is made at a place suitable to the story.
dictionaryExamples: The movie was shot on location in Kenya.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can't help mentioning the nice shots on location. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: driving or traveling, usually over a long distance
dictionaryExamples: We'd been on the road for 4 hours so we stopped to stretch and have a snack.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have experienced sitting behind a steering wheel on the road for many years. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Thai

sense.def: making progress and likely to succeed
dictionaryExamples: A fighter from Edinburgh is on track to become world heavyweight boxing champion.
We've got a lot of work to do but we're on the right track.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sales teams are well on track and bringing [in] new customers every day. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: being shown to the public
dictionaryExamples: Her designs are currently on show at the Museum of Modern Art.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the facilit[ies] that really make[s] a difference is the Art Gallery, with its great exhibition on show, as well as the Art Library. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: A food served on the side is served separate from the other foods.
dictionaryExamples: I’ll have the salad with the dressing on the side.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A common meal in my country will include soup and rice, a main dish is usually served with beans on the side and corn tortillas, all this is full of vitamins and calcium. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: inside a factory, office building, etc.
dictionaryExamples: There are two restaurants on site.
They provide on-site childcare facilities for employees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A small period of training on site is required a few days before the beginning of the job itself and how many interesting people you will meet! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

blocks.phrase: be on the verge of sth

sense.def: to be about to happen or be done very soon
dictionaryExamples: The company is on the verge of financial disaster.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was on the verge of depression, when I decided to take the control of my own life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to have something with you
dictionaryExamples: I don’t have my driver’s license on me.
Do you have any money on you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Make sure you have some cash in smaller bills on you, so you won't have problems paying for the ride. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to be extremely happy and excited
dictionaryExamples: When I heard I got the job, I was on cloud nine!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But now, after the promise in which both said "yes," she was on cloud nine. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: at that exact time
dictionaryExamples: We have to leave at 7:30 on the dot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He gave him an address and told him to be there at six on the dot. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to be nervous or worried
dictionaryExamples: Sorry for shouting - I'm a little on edge today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was consequently on edge all the time and was not able to have fun as much as the others did. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: used when you are describing how a situation seems on the surface
dictionaryExamples: On the face of it, this seems like a bargain, but I bet there are hidden costs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the face of it, both sides have valid arguments, and it's a difficult balancing act to manage. International English Language Testing System; C2; Urdu

sense.def: to be ready to deal with something difficult that might happen
dictionaryExamples: Companies were warned to be on their guard for suspicious packages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, we should be on guard, so as not to let the things escape our control. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: near to someone or something, and ready to help or be used when necessary
dictionaryExamples: Extra supplies will be on hand, in case they are needed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From their point of view, they can always have you on hand whenever they need help, which is the most important part in their formative years. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: suddenly and without thinking first
dictionaryExamples: I tend to act on impulse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm seeing Milly as a capricious girl who, like most teenagers, enjoy[s] buying, although I think that she buys on impulse. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: If someone's job, reputation, life, etc., is on the line, they may lose it.
dictionaryExamples: If we don't win the contract, all our jobs are on the line.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The person who hopes to achieve success shouldn't be afraid of taking risks and sometimes putting his or her career on the line for the sake of gaining much bigger benefits. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

blocks.phrase: on the spur of the moment

sense.def: If you do something on the spur of the moment, you do it suddenly, without planning it.
dictionaryExamples: On the spur of the moment we decided to go to London for the day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In reality, many people buy things on the spur of the moment only to discover later that they, in fact, do not [meet] their expect[at]ions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: sometimes, but not often
dictionaryExamples: He has, on occasion, told a small lie.

blocks.phrase: on the part of sb; on sb's part

sense.def: done or experienced by someone
dictionaryExamples: This is a major sacrifice on the part of the unions.
The accident was caused by carelessness on the instructor's part.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It seems that international sports competitions have always tended to attract a great amount of interest on the part of the media and have consistently been popular with sports fans the world over. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: to have a good/bad, etc. relationship with someone
dictionaryExamples: I'm still on friendly terms with my old colleagues.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The fact that they both live alone requires them to be on good terms with the rest of us.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If two people are on the same wavelength, they have the same way of thinking and it is easy for them to understand each other.
dictionaryExamples: We chatted occasionally, but I never really felt we were on the same wavelength.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were on the same wavelength and we therefore started our own research. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

blocks.phrase: be on the brink of sth

sense.def: to be in a situation where something bad is going to happen very soon
dictionaryExamples: The two countries are on the brink of war.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By the end of the 21st century, Earth was on the brink of destruction. The atmosphere was polluted, the seas were poisoned, the animals were just a distant memory.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: in addition to your main job
dictionaryExamples: She does some freelance work on the side.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At work, they gave her the worst jobs to do. She knew she didn't have much choice but she still tried to find something else on the side. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: immediately
dictionaryExamples: I accepted the job on the spot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And when it was Meredith's turn to tell her about her impending wedding, she felt she was going to have a heart attack on the spot. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If you have something on, you are wearing it.
dictionaryExamples: She has on a black coat.
Why don't you put your new dress on?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And I want you to put on some baggy clothes, so that you'll feel comfortable while working. Key English Test; A2; Rajasthani

sense.def: into a bus, train, plane, etc. or onto a horse
dictionaryExamples: It’s time to get on the bus.
The train suddenly started moving as I was stepping on.

sense.def: happening or planned
dictionaryExamples: I'm busy this afternoon, but I don't have anything on tomorrow.
Do you know what's on at the movies?
Is the party still on for tomorrow?

sense.def: working or being used
dictionaryExamples: The heating has been on all day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, the staff shouldn't leave the lights [on] and the heating's on when they don't need to use it. Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Arabic

sense.def: in a way which results in forward movement
dictionaryExamples: You continue on and I'll catch up.
Move on, please, and let the ambulance through.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had just got[ten] [o]n the subway when it stopped and didn't move on. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: performing
dictionaryExamples: Hurry up with the make-up - I'm on in ten minutes.
The audience cheered as the band came on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My faith in youth started to fade but then a boy named Josh came on. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: one single time
dictionaryExamples: I went sailing once, but I didn't like it.
I go swimming once a week.
We have lunch together once a month.
Once a year we all meet up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can write to him once a week. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: in the past, but not now
dictionaryExamples: This house once belonged to my grandfather.
Computers are much cheaper now than they once were.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I once went to England and I love the style of the clothes and how people dress there! Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: again
dictionaryExamples: Once again I'm left with all the dirty dishes!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Once again I'm sorry. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: one more time
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to visit the gardens once more before we leave.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On Friday I will see him once more. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: used at the beginning of a story to mean a long time ago
dictionaryExamples: Once upon a time there was a beautiful princess.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Once upon a time there was a very poor family. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: immediately
dictionaryExamples: I knew at once that I'd like it here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We both were so tired that we went to bed at once. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: at the same time
dictionaryExamples: They all started talking at once.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It give me a good chance to see most of my favorite groups at once, and it was marvelous. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: used to mean that something is happening that does not usually happen
dictionaryExamples: The bus came on time for once!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We would take lots of pictures, and play our own instruments, and if we get lucky enough, we would even touch the very stones and for once be embraced by magic itself. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: sometimes but not often
dictionaryExamples: We do go to the beach once in a while.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She did not say very much except for "oh" and "yes, yes" every once in a while. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: suddenly
dictionaryExamples: All at once he stood up and walked out of the room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All at once, everything started to work again. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: completely and finally
dictionaryExamples: We have to decide, once and for all, whether we want to ask Dad for money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With the fall of the socialist block in the late 1980's, the ever-looming nuclear war seemed to have been avoided once and for all. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: as soon as
dictionaryExamples: Once I find a place to live, I'll send you my address.
Remember that you won't be able to cancel the contract once you sign it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll write back soon once I know exactly when I can visit you. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the number 1
dictionaryExamples: You have three bags and I only have one.
one hundred and ninety-one people
Four packages came this morning, but only one was for Mark.
Paint one side, leave it to dry, and then paint the other.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She has got three da[ug]hters and one son. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu

sense.def: used to refer to a particular person or thing in a group that has already been talked about
dictionaryExamples: I've got a few books on Chinese cooking. You can borrow one if you like.
Which one would you like?
Would you make a copy for everybody in the office and a few extras for the visitors?
"Which cupcake would you like?" "The one in the front."
There were lots of people standing watching, and not one of them offered to help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got a lot of presents, but the best one was a watch from my sister. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: each other
dictionaryExamples: How can they reach an agreement if they won't talk to one another?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We know one another from Poland. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: separately, one after the other
dictionaryExamples: One by one the old buildings in the city have been demolished and replaced with modern glass towers.
They entered the room one by one.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, he decides to investigate his death and he meets Harry's friends, one by one, to [find out] how he died, but they tell him different stories. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: separately
dictionaryExamples: Eat them one at a time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The story was a horrible one but it had a harmless ending. The mad man kills one at a time, but in the end, the producer of the film says: "Cut, we'll take everything once again." First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: many, in a series, especially with very little time between them
dictionaryExamples: She read all four books one after another.
She ate the chocolates one after the other until the box was finished.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then all the good things came one after another. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: any person in general
dictionaryExamples: One ought to respect one's parents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One can learn the beauty of the Greek language by simply reading the headings and will [soon] find that "The Step" is the best newspaper of all. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: combined into a single thing
dictionaryExamples: It's a vacation and art course all in one.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Internet is like combining a television, a telephone and an airplane all in one. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to refer to a particular person or thing in a group
dictionaryExamples: One drawback is the cost of housing in the area.
One of our daughters just got married.
Our organization is just one  of many charities that are providing famine relief in the region.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of my presents was a dog! Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to talk about something that happened in the past
dictionaryExamples: One day, I came home to find my windows broken.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One day, I was reading an interesting book when someone called me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: at some time in the future
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to go to Berlin again one day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope one day I can become like that. Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese

sense.def: a few
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to make one or two suggestions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need more T shirts, new skate shoes and perhaps one or two pullovers. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used to refer to a time in the future that is not yet decided
dictionaryExamples: Why don't we meet for lunch one day next week?
I'd like to go skiing one Christmas.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would be very glad if Enrico could stay with you one summer. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: used to refer to a particular occasion while avoiding stating the exact moment
dictionaryExamples: I met him one day in the park.
One night we stayed up talking till dawn.
He was attacked as he was walking home from work late one afternoon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But one night, with the moon [br]ight, they felt encouraged to continue their walk. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a single thing
dictionaryExamples: Do you think five of us will manage to squeeze into one car?
There's too much data to fit onto just one disk.
I think we should paint the bedroom all one  color.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would recommend just the one hotel: Riverside Hotel, which offers great value. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish
