sense.def: used when saying there is no other person or thing
dictionaryExamples: He's the one person you can rely on in an emergency.
This may be your one and only  opportunity to meet her.
My final guest on tonight's show needs no introduction. Please welcome the one and only Michael Jordan!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Often it's the one and only possibility for young children to see wild animals or unknown animals from the other side of the world in real life. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: in some way that is not stated
dictionaryExamples: One way or another these bills have to be paid.
Everyone at the party was related in one way or another.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All of them made a big difference [to] our personal life and have affected it one way or another. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: in any way that is possible
dictionaryExamples: We have to make a decision one way or the other about what needs to be done.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even if we choose not to use computers personally, many of our transactions with society work through computer system[s] one way or the other. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: used to describe someone or something that is completely different from other people or things
dictionaryExamples: My Dad was one of a kind - funny, kind and generous.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Pele is indeed one of a kind and can be considered a model for youngsters. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the reflexive form of the pronoun "one" when it refers to the person speaking or people in general
dictionaryExamples: One needs to take care of oneself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One must ask oneself: "Why is this happening?" Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Slovene

sense.def: still happening
dictionaryExamples: an ongoing investigation/process/project
No agreement has yet been reached and the negotiations are still ongoing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, we are extremely positive about the club's future and its ongoing success. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a round vegetable with layers that has a strong taste and smell
dictionaryExamples: I always cry when I'm chopping onions.
Fry the onion and garlic for about two minutes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is cooked cab[b]age with beef, wild mushrooms and onion. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Czech

sense.def: describes products, services or information that can be bought or used on the Internet
dictionaryExamples: online banking/shopping
an online newspaper/magazine/dictionary
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like it very much, because I can play online games now. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: bought, used, etc. using the Internet
dictionaryExamples: I ordered them online.
Why don't you go online and see what you can find?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When we went back home, I went online and checked my e-mails. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: not more than a particular size or amount
dictionaryExamples: She's only 13.
These shoes only cost £20.
He passed only one of his exams.
It's only four o'clock and  it's already getting dark.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is only ten minutes by car. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: not anyone or anything else
dictionaryExamples: Only Sue and Mark came to the meeting.
This club is for members only.
Only food bought here may be eaten here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Only Marco, Anna, Sue and Nick came. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: not in any other place
dictionaryExamples: These televisions are only available in Japan.
These birds are only found in New Zealand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think animals, just as human beings, can only live in their natural habitat. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: used to mean that something happened very recently
dictionaryExamples: I only arrived half an hour ago.
They only put the roof on last week.
The movie had only just begun.
We'd only just started out when the car broke down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am really sorry I didn't write back earlier but I have only just got back from holiday. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used to say that something is not important, or that you did not mean to upset someone
dictionaryExamples: Don't worry - it's only a scratch.
I was only joking.
I was only trying to help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was only a dream! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used when you want to say how doing something simple would make it possible to avoid something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: If only they'd listen to him, I'm sure they could work it out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If only I had been more careful. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: used to emphasize what you are hoping or wishing for
dictionaryExamples: I only hope you know what you're doing.
I only wish that they would keep in touch more.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I only hope I can have the chance to see her too. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that more than one thing is true
dictionaryExamples: Not only did he turn up late, he also forgot his books.
If this project fails it will affect not only our department, but the whole organization.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not only did she introduce me to her friends but she also introduced me to her brother. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: used to say that there are limits to something
dictionaryExamples: There's only so much help you can give someone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The effects of a longer life span have many side ef[f]ects such as an increase in the world's population and, since there is only so much food, m[any] more people are st[ar]ving to death. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: used to mean that there are not any others
dictionaryExamples: This is our only chance.
I was the only person on the train.
Is this really the only way to do it?
The only thing that matters is that the baby is healthy.
It was the only thing I could do under the circumstances.
Rita was the only person to complain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am the only French student in my class. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: to not be perfect
dictionaryExamples: Of course Tom makes mistakes - he's only human.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  In theory, it is easy to say "We should learn from the mistakes of the past" but is it easy to do so in practice? Many people would say "No" to this question, as we are only human. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: used to introduce a statement which explains why something you have just said cannot happen or is not completely true
dictionaryExamples: This fabric is similar to wool, only  cheaper.
I would have left earlier, only you didn’t want to.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was always there for me when I needed him, only I needed him less and less. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: used to show movement into or on a particular place
dictionaryExamples: I slipped as I stepped onto the platform.
The crates were loaded onto trucks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We couldn't talk so much, because the music was very loud till a group of singers came onto the dance floor and [did] a great show. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: used to show that you are starting to talk about a different subject
dictionaryExamples: How did we get onto this subject?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Let's move onto another topic! First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: available for business or serving customers
dictionaryExamples: The supermarket is open till 10.00 p.m.
Our phone lines are open until 9 pm Central time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are open all day and all night. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: not closed or fastened
dictionaryExamples: an open door/window
Her open suitcase was on the dresser.
You left the box open.
Someone had left the window wide  open.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The door was open! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: An open area of land has no buildings on it or near it.
dictionaryExamples: large open spaces
There's a wonderful view from the garden over open countryside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need to be outside in open spaces. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to wait until you know all the facts before you form an opinion about something or judge someone
dictionaryExamples: We're keeping an open mind about the causes of the fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To listen, to communicate, [and] to have an open mind are a way of life [nowadays]. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: without a roof or cover
dictionaryExamples: an open courtyard
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You took me to a sightseeing trip around the town in an open car. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: willing to consider a discussion/suggestions, etc.
dictionaryExamples: This is only a proposal. I'm open to suggestions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He seems open to ideas like this, and I am sure he will not cancel at the last minute! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: An open person is honest and not trying to hide something.
dictionaryExamples: He's quite open about his weaknesses.
I wish you'd be more open with me, and tell me what you're feeling.
She has an honest, open face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He has also been very open about his diabetes and the problems connected with the disease. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: not secret
dictionaryExamples: There has been open hostility between them ever since they had that argument last summer.
The candidate has promised an open debate on the issue.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The council has refused to have an open discussion with the residents. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: can easily be debated/questioned/criticized, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Their behavior at these negotiations is open to criticism.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Whether the wages of sportswomen and sportsmen are too high is open to question. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to move something to a position that is not closed, or to make something change to a position that is not closed
dictionaryExamples: to open a door/window
The gate won't open.
You can open your eyes now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can't open my cupboard without my key. Key English Test; A2; Korean

sense.def: to remove or separate part of a container or package so that you can see or use what it contains
dictionaryExamples: Shall I open another bottle of water?
I haven't even opened the letter yet.
She can't wait to open all her presents.
He opened the box and a kitten jumped out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First I opened my presents. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: If a store or office opens at a particular time of day, it starts to do business at that time.
dictionaryExamples: The coffee shop opens at ten o'clock.
What time does the bank open?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is open every day of the week except Mondays; it opens at 9:00 am and close[s] at 10:00 pm. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to make a computer document or program ready to be read or used
dictionaryExamples: First, open the file called "statistics."

sense.def: If a business or activity opens, it starts officially for the first time, and if you open it, you make it start officially for the first time.
dictionaryExamples: That restaurant's new - it only opened last month.
The Olympic Games open tomorrow.
The new hospital will be officially opened by the mayor on Tuesday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am very happy to announce [to] you that a new museum has been opened in our town. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to tell someone your secret thoughts and feelings
dictionaryExamples: That night, she opened her heart to me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is during this excessively dramatic conversation that George opening up his heart, tells her about his interpretation of her unhappiness with Cecil. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to watch carefully for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Keep your eyes open for anything unusual.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: While staying in Turkey, for example, people ought to keep their eyes open. Look into life there. 
 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to start a new store or business
dictionaryExamples: Several banks have recently opened up branches downtown.
Fast food restaurants are opening up everywhere you look.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We could set up hiking tours, mini-excursions in the mountains, survival camps. [...] With th[ese] kind[s] of activities, the village would need to open up more shops, restaurants, coffee shops etc. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to start to talk more about yourself and your feelings
dictionaryExamples: I've tried to get him to open up to me but without success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even when I tried to open up to my best friend, he laughed at me and said that I should go to a psychiatr[ist]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a ceremony at the beginning of an event or activity
dictionaryExamples: The official opening of the new school will take place next month.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The festival starts with a huge opening parade. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: the beginning of something
dictionaryExamples: The opening of the novel is amazing.

sense.def: a hole or space that something or someone can pass through
dictionaryExamples: The children crawled through an opening in the fence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The water in the reservoir is allowed to flow [through] an opening in the dam. International English Language Testing System; C2; Ibo/Igbo

sense.def: happening at the beginning of an event or activity
dictionaryExamples: her opening remarks
the opening night
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also we could offer free drinks from our new products [on] the opening night, so we could [get] their first impressions. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: without hiding any of your thoughts or feelings
dictionaryExamples: They were openly dismissive of my suggestions.
He talks quite openly about his feelings.
We discussed our reservations about the contract quite openly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I do hope that you are willing to cooperate, though I cannot say it openly. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: willing to consider ideas and opinions that are new or different from your own
dictionaryExamples: Luckily, both my parents were very open-minded.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is also open-minded and very reliable. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: willingness to talk about your thoughts and feelings
dictionaryExamples: I appreciated his openness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, I have found honesty and openness significantly important. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a musical play in which most of the words are sung
dictionaryExamples: "Carmen" is my favorite opera.
I've never been a huge fan of opera.
He goes to the opera  whenever he can.
an opera singer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like classical music and opera. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: to treat an illness or injury by cutting someone's body and removing or repairing part of it
dictionaryExamples: Did they have to operate on him?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One day he decided to give part of his money to his son, whose wife was sick and had to be operated [on] immediately. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If a machine operates, it does what it is designed to do, and if you operate it, you make it do what it is designed to do.
dictionaryExamples: You have to be trained to operate the machinery.
These new sewing machines are easy to operate.
How do you operate the remote control?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lots of things are operated by computers now like airplanes, elevators, ticket machines, and so on. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: If an organization or business operates, it is working, and if you operate it, you manage it and make it work.
dictionaryExamples: Our company is operating under very difficult conditions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a new direct transportation service from London, operated by ABC coaches. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a medical procedure where a doctor cuts someone's body to remove or repair part of it
dictionaryExamples: a major/minor operation
He's got to have an operation on his shoulder.
We will know in a couple of days if the operation to restore her sight was successful.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sorry that I can't attend the class tomorrow because my father is having an operation tomorrow. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: an activity that is planned in order to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: a military/peacekeeping operation
Following the earthquake, a large-scale rescue operation was launched.
The operation to fly in supplies will begin as soon as possible.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An attempt to follow a lecture on the U.N.O. peace-keeping operations can be [a] real difficulty if you are not able to listen to CNN News by now. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: an organization or business
dictionaryExamples: a large commercial operation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I cannot receive any satisfactory reply this month, I will write to the newspaper to expose your operation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: the fact of operating or being active
dictionaryExamples: Several printing presses are in operation at the moment.
There are several reactors of this type in operation  at the moment.
The new assembly line will begin operation next year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We see computers in operation at work as well as in almost every home. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: someone whose job is to use and control a machine or vehicle
dictionaryExamples: an camera/elevator/crane operator
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last year I was working in a printing company as a Macintosh operator. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a company that does a particular type of business
dictionaryExamples: a tour operator
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If once more we are not satisfied, tour operators organize several types of safari holidays wherever we like. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a thought or belief about something or someone
dictionaryExamples: What's your opinion about/on this plan?
Some people always have strong opinions.
He didn't express/give an opinion on the matter.
Who, in your opinion,  is the best player in the league?
Her opinion of Adam changed after he'd been so helpful at the wedding.
I want to get a second opinion on whether I need knee surgery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really enjoy shopping for clothes especial[l]y when I go shopping with my brother, because I sometimes ask him for his opinion. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: the thoughts or beliefs that a group of people have
dictionaryExamples: The advertising campaign is intended to influence public opinion.
There is a wide range of opinion on the issue.
We have a difference of opinion among the committee members.
Opinion is divided as to whether the treatment actually works.
Both performances were excellent, it's simply a matter of opinion as to whose was better.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to add that when it comes to public opinion there is a great variety of different points of view - that is why this article, which asserts that "performers were second-rate'' seems to be unfair. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

blocks.phrase: have a high/low opinion of sb/sth

sense.def: to think that someone or something is good/bad
dictionaryExamples: He has a low opinion of doctors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He had a very high opinion of this particular course. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: used to give your opinion about something, often when you are sure you are right
dictionaryExamples: In my humble opinion, that's the wrong decision.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my humble opinion, there's no such thing as a uniform celebrity, good, bad or otherwise. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: someone who you compete against in a game or competition
dictionaryExamples: In the second game, her opponent hurt her leg and couldn't continue to play.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Carmelita was her opponent in the vol[l]eyball final. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who disagrees with an action or belief and tries to change it
dictionaryExamples: a political opponent
Leading opponents of the proposed spending cuts will meet later today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lots of people think that zoos are necessary and good; their opponents demand [we] close all zoos because in their opinion they are cruel prisons for animals. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a situation in which it is possible for you to do something, or a possibility of doing something
dictionaryExamples: Everyone will have an opportunity to comment.
The exhibition is a unique opportunity to see her later work.
An ankle injury meant she missed the opportunity to take part in the race.
He goes fishing at every opportunity.
Please contact us at the earliest opportunity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a good opportunity to spend time with your friends. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: the chance to get a job
dictionaryExamples: employment/job opportunities
opportunities for recent graduates
There are fewer opportunities this year for for young people looking for summer jobs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And many people don't have any other job opportunities so they would be stuck with [these] bad jobs. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

blocks.phrase: take the/this opportunity to do sth

sense.def: to use an occasion to do or say something
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to take this opportunity to thank all of you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most of the comments [are] not right at all. I would like to take this opportunity to correct them. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to disagree with a plan or activity and to try to change or stop it
dictionaryExamples: They both opposed the plan.
Most of the local people opposed closing the hospital.
The proposed new standardized tests have been vigorously opposed by teachers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of them were defending the idea that the car is the most lethal object that anybody can have, and others who opposed that idea said that the car is and [will] always be the best invention made by humanity. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: in a position facing someone or something but on the other side
dictionaryExamples: We're in the building opposite the library.
They sat opposite each other.
Put a check mark opposite  the answer that you think is correct.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's near the park and opposite the bank, so it isn't far. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: in a position facing something or someone but on the other side
dictionaryExamples: My brother and I live on opposite sides of town.
The map on the opposite page shows the main lakes in the area.
They sat at opposite ends of the table, refusing to talk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [O]n the opposite side, there is a dark brown wardro[be] which is made of wood. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: completely different
dictionaryExamples: All the traffic was going in the opposite direction.
Attempts to calm everyone down had the opposite effect.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The uncle had warned her so that she wouldn't interfer[e] with what happened at the inn, but it had the opposite effect on Mary. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: people who are the other sex from you
dictionaryExamples: When you attend an all girls or all boys school, you don't study with members of the opposite sex.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is not only about trying to impress (preferably) a person of the opposite sex, but fashion also gives you a great chance to express yourself. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: something or someone that is completely different from another person or thing
dictionaryExamples: The opposite of "fast" is "slow."
My father is a very calm person, but my mother is just the opposite.
She turned out to be the exact opposite of what everyone expected.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Physically, she's the opposite of me. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: in a position facing someone or something but on the other side
dictionaryExamples: She asked the man sitting opposite whether he'd mind if she opened the window.
The people who live opposite us  are always making a lot of noise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was on the pavement next to my house and I was calling to my friend, when suddenly I saw a man who [was] just going around to my neighbour's car, which was parked opposite. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Polish

sense.def: strong disagreement
dictionaryExamples: The proposal faces strong opposition.
During the tow council meeting, several members of the public spoke out in opposition to the plan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The students, in an attempt to demonstrate the opposition of the Greek people to the military regime, occupied their schools for many days. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the people or group not in power, especially a political party that does not have an elected majority
dictionaryExamples: They expect to defeat the local opposition in Tuesday's election.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was elected MP for a record of 9 times [and] was the leader of EPE for many years, leading the opposition when Georgios Papandreou, Andreas' father was in power. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to choose something or to decide to do something
dictionaryExamples: Mike opted for early retirement.
Most people opt to have the operation.
He opted out of the health insurance plan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My recommendation today is to take in[to] consideration people's views and opt for the Park and Ride. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: when you believe good things will happen
dictionaryExamples: There was a note of optimism in his voice as he spoke about the company's future.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had never been abroad on our own and our hearts were full with a mixture of optimism, curiosity and absurd fears. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: someone who always believes that good things will happen
dictionaryExamples: She's an optimist.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is an incurable optimist with a great sense of humor. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: always believing that good things will happen
dictionaryExamples: She is optimistic about her chances of winning a gold medal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm not very optimistic about them being sensitive enough to try to produce [fewer] cars, putting human life before their profits. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a choice
dictionaryExamples: We don't have many options.
I'm still considering my options.
The program helps students explore career options.
The best option would be to cancel the trip altogether.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Think about it a little bit and choose the option you think is the best. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

blocks.phrase: have no option (but to do sth)

sense.def: to not have the possibility of doing something else
dictionaryExamples: We didn't want to let him go, but we had no option.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, [on] the first day, Monday, students have the day free with their host parents but there are some of them who work all day and the students have no option but to stay alone in the house. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: If something is optional, you can choose whether to do it, pay it, buy it, etc.
dictionaryExamples: English is required for all students, but art and music are optional.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Refer[r]ing to optional lessons, it was recommended that Speaking and Listening, Computer [Studies] and Business English are suitable for filming. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: used between possibilities, or before the last in a list of possibilities
dictionaryExamples: Would you like tea or coffee?
Is that a boy or a girl?
You can have beer, wine or mineral water.
It was either 1982 or 1983 - I can't remember which.
There were ten or twelve  people in the room.
It will only take three or four days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to eat pasta or pizza, but I'm easy about food, I can eat anything. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: used after a negative verb to mean not one thing and also not another
dictionaryExamples: Tim doesn't eat meat or fish.
She doesn't have a telephone or a computer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: OH! and please don't wear jeans or white clothes. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: used to express the possibility that something might not happen
dictionaryExamples: Are you going to reply or not?
I still don't know whether she's coming or not.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Are [you] busy or not that day? Key English Test; A2; Singhalese

sense.def: used to give someone a warning or advice
dictionaryExamples: You should eat more, or you'll get sick.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She called "Bill, come here or you'll be in trouble". Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: approximately
dictionaryExamples: I think we raised five hundred dollars or so for the charity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well you told me about your situation and after thinking a lot I thought you should go with them for a week or so, and then just take a plane and come to Barcelona to visit me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: used to indicate a very small number, often no more than two
dictionaryExamples: We will spend a day or two in Boston.
Mom said I can bring a friend or two with me.
I'd like to ask our guest of honor to say a word or two.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The thing you can do, is go out with your family first and than with your friends, or, you can ask your parents, if you can invite a friend or two to go with you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to change or correct something you have said
dictionaryExamples: We told the truth, or most of it.
Eleanor, or Ellie to her friends, took the initiative.
Things have been going well recently. Or they were, up until two days ago.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is the one [who goes] around with all Rebecca's secrets. Or, almost all the secrets. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: used to say what will happen if another thing does not happen
dictionaryExamples: We have to be there by six, or else we'll miss the beginning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [He] told me to hurry up, or else I would miss my bus. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: used when you cannot or do not want to be exact about the information you are giving
dictionaryExamples: The event was held in some park or other.
We'll find someone or other to help us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe you hate the memory of boring literature classes at school, but I'm sure each of you is interested in some subject or other. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: used to give a reason for, explain, or correct something you have said
dictionaryExamples: Things were going well, or seemed to be, but the relationship had already begun to change.
She must love her work or she wouldn't have kept at it all these years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [have] stud[ied] music since I was twelve or, in other words, I started to learn how to read music and how to play an instrument about ten years ago. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: spoken, not written
dictionaryExamples: an oral agreement/exam
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum it up, watching TV improves our oral skills and is a better way of taking notice of the world outside, whereas books improve our writing and reading skills. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: being a color that is a mixture of red and yellow
dictionaryExamples: The setting sun filled the sky with a deep orange glow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I bought two orange T-shirts. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a round, sweet fruit with a thick skin and a center that is divided into many equal parts
dictionaryExamples: Do you want to get some oranges?
a glass of orange juice
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like eating a sandwich with Flora and I like drinking tea with sugar or orange juice. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a color between red and yellow
dictionaryExamples: His car is a bright orange.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My bedroom will be orange.  I love orange, and please come with old clothes. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a large group of musicians who play different instruments together
dictionaryExamples: a symphony orchestra
She's a violinist with/in the Boston Symphony Orchestra.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So last Thursday evening we went together [to] the club and there he introduced me to the ch[o]ir director, a friendly man from Argentina who also plays cello in the orchestra. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: played by, written for or to do with an orchestra
dictionaryExamples: an orchestral arrangement
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The lyrics are about life, love, pain and death but the most important thing is how th[ese] lyrics match with the orchestral part of the song. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a very unpleasant experience
dictionaryExamples: Her seven-month stay in the hospital was quite an ordeal.
They feared he would not survive the ordeal.
She went through the ordeal of being interviewed by a panel of ten people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Despite the unfavorable memory of this ordeal, I am of the opinion that, not only are family gatherings important in themselves, but also, I consider them to be crucial to the very existence of humanity. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a request to make, supply or deliver food or goods
dictionaryExamples: Did the waiter take our order yet?
I would like to place  an order for a large pine table.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You either have to flip burgers or take customers' orders. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: the way in which people or things are arranged, either in relation to one another or according to a particular characteristic
dictionaryExamples: The children lined up in age/height order.
I can't find the file I need because they're all out of order.
I put the files in alphabetical order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is the order of the wedding [ceremony]: first the man and the woman enter the church together. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

blocks.phrase: in order (for sb/sth) to do sth

sense.def: with the purpose of achieving something
dictionaryExamples: He came home early in order to see the children before they went to bed.
She worked all summer in order to save enough money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She will go to the United States in order to improve her English. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: If a machine or system is out of order, it is not working correctly.
dictionaryExamples: The coffee machine is out of order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last week my TV was out of order. Preliminary English Test; B1; Dutch

sense.def: an instruction that someone must obey
dictionaryExamples: The company received an order to stop releasing the polluting chemicals  into the river.
The troops are supposed to obey orders given by an officer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today I can still remember my last order: "Put that light out!" First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a situation in which everything is in its correct place
dictionaryExamples: I like for everything to be in order before I go away.
The house was such a mess that she spent the whole day trying to establish some sort of order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everthing was clean and in order. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a situation in which people obey laws and there is no trouble
dictionaryExamples: The teacher found it hard to keep her class in order.
As the demonstration began to turn violent, the police were called in to restore order.
After some heated discussion, the chair called  the meeting to order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some young people began to be aggressive, putting everything in a mess; some policemen trying to restore order even got wounded. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the way that the economy, politics, or society is organized
dictionaryExamples: a threat to the established social order
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The failure of the social order Ralph tries to establish and the success of beautifully painted hunters led by Jack, hunting pigs up in the mountains, slowly makes the number of Ralph's supporters diminish. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a situation in which people obey laws and there is no trouble
dictionaryExamples: The teacher found it hard to keep her class in order.
As the demonstration began to turn violent, the police were called in to restore order.
After some heated discussion, the chair called  the meeting to order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some young people began to be aggressive, putting everything in a mess; some policemen trying to restore order even got wounded. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the way that the economy, politics, or society is organized
dictionaryExamples: a threat to the established social order
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The failure of the social order Ralph tries to establish and the success of beautifully painted hunters led by Jack, hunting pigs up in the mountains, slowly makes the number of Ralph's supporters diminish. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a situation in which people obey laws and there is no trouble
dictionaryExamples: The teacher found it hard to keep her class in order.
As the demonstration began to turn violent, the police were called in to restore order.
After some heated discussion, the chair called  the meeting to order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some young people began to be aggressive, putting everything in a mess; some policemen trying to restore order even got wounded. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the way that the economy, politics, or society is organized
dictionaryExamples: a threat to the established social order
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The failure of the social order Ralph tries to establish and the success of beautifully painted hunters led by Jack, hunting pigs up in the mountains, slowly makes the number of Ralph's supporters diminish. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a situation in which people obey laws and there is no trouble
dictionaryExamples: The teacher found it hard to keep her class in order.
Observers were present to preserve order during the voting.
When heated disagreement broke out, the chairman tried to restore order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some young people began to be aggressive, putting everything in a mess; some policemen trying to restore order even got wounded. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the way that the economy, politics, or society is organized
dictionaryExamples: a threat to the established social order
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The failure of the social order Ralph tries to establish and the success of beautifully painted hunters led by Jack, hunting pigs up in the mountains, slowly makes the number of Ralph's supporters diminish. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the obeying of laws in society
dictionaryExamples: a breakdown in law and order
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The breakdown in law and order, lack of basic amenities to support life, absence of a fair and enabling enviro[n]ment for citizens to thrive, to mention but a few, are some among many factors [that] constitute the cogent reason why most Nigerians choose to travel out of their own country. International English Language Testing System; C2; Efik

sense.def: to ask for food, goods, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I ordered the pasta and a mixed salad.
There are no shirts left in this size but we could order one for you/order you one.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After 15 minutes I ordered a "Party Pizza." Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: to give someone an instruction that they must obey
dictionaryExamples: The management has ordered a cutback in spending.
"Wait over there," she ordered.
They ordered him to leave the room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, the men ordered him to walk back to the museum as if not[hing] had happened. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: not special, different, or unusual in any way
dictionaryExamples: These are ordinary people living ordinary lives.
It was just an ordinary house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the afternoon I prefer jean shorts or skirts with an ordinary t-shirt and sandals. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: unusual or different
dictionaryExamples: The investigation revealed nothing out of the ordinary.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This event is something out of the ordinary for local life and it gives our town prestige and originality. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a part of an animal or plant that has a special purpose
dictionaryExamples: internal/vital organs
an organ donor/transplant
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now you can replace or heal almost every bone or organ in a human body. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: a musical instrument that has one or more rows of keys like a piano that when pressed produce sound by causing air to blow through pipes or electronically
dictionaryExamples: a pipe organ
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I played the piano for three hours every day, took organ lessons and at the age of 10 started to write programs on my home computer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: not using artificial chemicals when keeping animals or growing plants for food
dictionaryExamples: organic food/vegetables/meat
organic farming
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also, people care more about what really is in the food they eat and so interest in organic food is increasing. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: an official group of people who work together for the same purpose
dictionaryExamples: the World Health Organization
The article was about international aid organizations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She decided [on] st[u]dying abroad 2 years ago, applied to several organizations, got invitations to a few interviews with these organizations and finally got the 'OK' to go to the USA for one year. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the planning of an activity or event
dictionaryExamples: He didn't want to be involved in the organization of/for the conference, although he agreed to attend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need to change the time of our meeting because my boss tell[s] me that I have to work two more hours [o]n the organization for the party of the year. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the way that parts of something are arranged
dictionaryExamples: I'm trying to improve the organization of my computer files.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The organization of books, magazines and references is fantastic. International English Language Testing System; C1; Arabic

sense.def: to plan or arrange something
dictionaryExamples: He organized the whole event.
They organized a meeting between the teachers and students.
She had organized a car to meet me at the airport.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Why don't you organize a dinner with your parents and your friends? Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to do or arrange something according to a particular system
dictionaryExamples: The books are organized by author, not by title.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now Museums are big, have lots of light and you can find the la[te]st technology in them. They are organized in such a different way. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: able to plan things carefully and keep things neat
dictionaryExamples: She's not a very organized person and she always arrives late for meetings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know you're a very organized person so tell me which CDs I can use. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: planned or arranged
dictionaryExamples: We didn't go on an organized tour.
The letters had been placed in organized piles, one for each letter of the alphabet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a well-kept and organized place for animals to live. First Certificate in English; B2; Estonian

sense.def: someone who plans an event or activity
dictionaryExamples: conference/exhibition organizers
There aren't enough seats for all the guests - I have to tell the organizers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have been working as a social activity organizer for 5 years at the English Language School. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: the position of something in relation to its surroundings
dictionaryExamples: The building has an east-west orientation.
If you feel lost, you can look up to find a familiar tall building and use it for orientation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The information pack was really good but it would be helpful if you could include a map for orientation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: training or preparation for a new job or activity
dictionaryExamples: Orientation for new students begins Wednesday afternoon.
an orientation session
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I may require some training or orientation should you be using specialized cleaning tools or equipment. International English Language Testing System; C2; Chinese

sense.def: the interests, activities, or beliefs that a person has
dictionaryExamples: He  has never tried to hide his political orientation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Choices about friends, hobbies, professional orientation, have to start in the children, and it is the task of the parents not to restrict the power to choose, but advise them using their own experience, and to provide a safe environment where the final choice of the child, how ever free, won't entail any danger to him or her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the cause of something, or where something begins or comes from
dictionaryExamples: What's the origin of that saying?
It's a book about the origins of the universe.
The furniture was French in origin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The cooking [is] base[d] on traditional recipes of Westfalian origin and it is tasty but often very rich! First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the country, race, or social class of a person's family
dictionaryExamples: He is of North African origin.
What is your countryof origin?
The president's family was of humble origins.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The rules are very simple, they can be understood by everyone, regardless of age, origin or social status. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: existing since the beginning, or being the earliest form of something
dictionaryExamples: That was my original plan.
Is this the original fireplace?
The gardens have recently been restored to their original glory.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They chose th[is] school because it looks very similar to the original school where that old series was made. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: special and interesting because of not being the same as others
dictionaryExamples: Her essay was full of original ideas.
He's a highly original thinker.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to be original. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: describes a piece of work produced by an artist and not a copy
dictionaryExamples: an original drawing/manuscript
Is this an original Rembrandt?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We visited Mozart's house, where we could see not only how he lived, but also admire some of his original sc[ore]s. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: something that is in the form in which it was first created and has not been copied or changed
dictionaryExamples: If the painting is an original, it will be very valuable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was paying him, but not as much as she would need to [to] buy the original. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: at the beginning or before any changes
dictionaryExamples: Originally it was a bedroom, but we turned it into a study.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've been living in England for 6 months and I have studied English for 8 years in Sweden, where I was originally born. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: an attractive object that is used as a decoration in a home or garden
dictionaryExamples: There were glass ornaments on the shelf.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Expensive products such as necklaces and decorative ornaments are highly represented, much to the joy of the more wealthy people in the town. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a child whose parents have died
dictionaryExamples: They adopted an orphan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Vanyka" is [a] story about a nine-year-old orphan sent to Moscow to work as a servant in a rich [person's] house. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Serbian

sense.def: If ideas or methods are orthodox, most people think they are correct, usually because they have existed for a long time.
dictionaryExamples: orthodox methods of teaching
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To tell the truth, I was brought up in a rather orthodox way.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: keeping a particular traditional set of religious beliefs and customs
dictionaryExamples: an orthodox Jewish family
the Russian/Greek Orthodox Church
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a celebration, a hymn to love, and honors the memory of St Hyacinth, an orthodox martyr who died for his faith. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: as well as the person or thing already mentioned
dictionaryExamples: There is only one other person who could help us.
Are there any other people we should tell?
The product has many other features.
There is no other work available at this time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She likes meeting other people because she wants [to] improve her English. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Nepali

sense.def: used to talk about the remaining members of a group or items in a set
dictionaryExamples: Mario and Anna sat down to watch the other dancers.
I've found one earring - do you know where the other one is?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One part is green [and] the other part is blue. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: different from the thing or person already mentioned
dictionaryExamples: I don't have any cash - is there no other way of paying?
Ask me some other time when I'm not so busy.
He likes traveling and learning about other people's customs and traditions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The two kids [had] waited [long] enough so they decided to walk. The girl asked: "Is there any other way the Man [can] hurt us?"  Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: the opposite side or end of something
dictionaryExamples: Put the chair at the other end of the table.
The man was waiting on the other side of the street.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll move my bed to the other side of my room. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: referring to a day, week, etc. in the recent past without saying exactly when it was
dictionaryExamples: I saw him just the other day/night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear John, Thanks for the letter you wrote me the other day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to introduce an explanation that is simpler than the one given earlier
dictionaryExamples: He was economical with the truth - in other words, he was lying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are able to use zoos as a place where we c[an] spend our free time with our children. In other words, it is a good place for the family. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: happening in the opposite way
dictionaryExamples: I thought the older people would be more offended than the young people, but it was the other way around.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are controlling us and not the other way around. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: used when you cannot or do not want to be exact about the information you are giving
dictionaryExamples: The event was held in some park or other.
We'll find someone or other to help us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe you hate the memory of boring literature classes at school, but I'm sure each of you is interested in some subject or other. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: different from or except
dictionaryExamples: The form cannot be signed by anyone other than you.
There's nothing on TV tonight, other than reruns.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are no vegetarian alternatives other than cheese sandwiches, which our members find very depressi[ng]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: except for the thing you have just said
dictionaryExamples: My arm was a bit sore - other than that I was fine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Curren[t]ly, I only have a small corner in the room whereas my sisters get a bigger portion. This means I have to keep all my things under the bed. Other than that, I would like a big beautiful garden because I love nature. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: happening every two days/weeks, etc., not each day/week, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Alice goes to the gym every other day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First, I would run 2 miles every other day, but soon it became a need to do it on a daily basis. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: used to refer to a person or thing which belongs to a group or set that you have already talked about
dictionaryExamples: Hold the racket in one hand and the ball in the other.
She gave me one book last week and promised to bring the others on Wednesday.
Some people prefer living in the city, but others perfer the suburbs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really wanted you [to] come with me and the others. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to show that each person in a group of two or more people does something to the others
dictionaryExamples: They kept looking at each other and smiling.
They're always wearing each other's clothes.
Why are you always arguing with each other?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can write to each other once a month. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: people in general, not including yourself
dictionaryExamples: You shouldn't expect others to do your work for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that I would be very useful there, because I know that they need people who enjoy helping others and I am one of those [people]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: more similar ones
dictionaryExamples: This one is broken - do you have any others?
I only know about this book, but there might be others.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact, we [might] manage to do some interesting activities such as mountain biking in Sintra, canoeing in Teja, etc. You would be glad to see how many interesting people we [might] meet while doing those activities and any others that you would like to [do]. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to say what the result would be if something else did not happen
dictionaryExamples: I'd better write it down, otherwise I'll forget it.
Cory wants to know if we want the tickets, otherwise she'll ask Ann.
You really must phone home. Otherwise, your parents will start to worry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Oh! I'll have to buy a table for the computer. Otherwise, I'll have to use my computer on my bed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: except for what has just been referred to
dictionaryExamples: The bike needs a new saddle, but otherwise it's in good condition.
The poor sound quality ruined an otherwise splendid film.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This seemed the high point of an otherwise dull and disorgani[z]ed event. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: differently than what has been stated
dictionaryExamples: I'll meet you there at 6 o'clock, unless I hear otherwise.
Under the law, a person is presumed innocent until proved otherwise.
Marion Morrison, otherwise known as the film star John Wayne, was born in 1907.
Parts of the company will be sold or otherwise dismantled.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An important event in the history of Greece was the Civil War between the cities of Athens and Spart[a] around 400 B.C., otherwise known as [the] Pelopon[n]esian War. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: used to say or ask what is the correct or best thing to do
dictionaryExamples: We ought to clean  up before we go home.
You ought to see a doctor.
She really ought to apologize.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I ought to go to the doctor tomorrow. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to say that you expect something to be true or that you expect something to happen
dictionaryExamples: She ought to be home by now.
He ought to get his test results on Thursday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the students ought to know how famous you are. You are a very well-known writer who was born in Rhodes. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a unit for measuring weight, equal to 1/16 pound or 28.35 grams
dictionaryExamples: Add four ounces of butter.

sense.def: a very small amount of something such as a quality or emotion
dictionaryExamples: If he’s got an ounce of common sense, he’ll realize that this project is bound to fail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I trained a lot, putting my last ounce of energy into the process, determined to win. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: belonging to or relating to us
dictionaryExamples: We bought our house several years ago.
He walked off and left us on our own.
Our plans have changed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every day, we have to give our teacher our homework. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: used to show that something belongs to or is connected with the person who is speaking and one or more other people
dictionaryExamples: Which table is ours?
He's a cousin of ours.
I think these seats are ours.
Their daughter is the same age as ours.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We met a lot of friends of ours. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the reflexive form of the pronoun "we"
dictionaryExamples: We really enjoyed ourselves.
We promised ourselves a good vacation this year.
The hotel was very quiet so we had the swimming pool all to ourselves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We all enjoyed ourselves very much at the party. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: alone or without anyone else's help
dictionaryExamples: We finished the work by ourselves.
Will we be able to do it ourselves or will we need help?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway, we had to try to fix the stupid car by ourselves. First Certificate in English; B2; Norwegian

sense.def: used to refer to a period of time when someone goes away from home for a social activity
dictionaryExamples: He's out nearly every night.
He asked me out  to see a movie next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the film, we can have dinner out. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: not in the place where you usually live or work, especially for a short time
dictionaryExamples: I came by to see you this morning, but you were out.
Someone called looking for you while you were out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Will you give [it] back to my father because I am out for a while. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: used to show movement away from the inside of a place or container
dictionaryExamples: Get out!
She opened the window and stuck her head out.
The bag burst and the apples fell out.
He opened the drawer and took out a pair of socks.
My secretary will see you out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I was on the plane, I decided to open my suitcase to take out my CD player because I was bored. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: able to be seen
dictionaryExamples: The stars are out tonight.
The rain stopped and the sun came out.
The flowers are starting to come out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the beginning it was raining a little bit, but then the sun came out. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: available to buy or see
dictionaryExamples: Is the new Harry Potter book out yet?
The new Tarantino movie comes out in August.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It came out just yesterday. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: to the point where something is removed or disappears
dictionaryExamples: The stain won't come out.
Cross out any words that are not on the list.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A friend of mine told me, when he was in Lampton, that you couldn't have special rates for students at Hotel Royal, so you should cross [that information] out of the guide. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: If you say or read something out loud, you say or read it so that other people can hear you.
dictionaryExamples: I had to read the essay out loud in front of the whole school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She wouldn't accept it so I read [it] out loud for her to hear: "Director, Jason Meyer, and producer, Sami Woods, are receiving...". Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: If a light or fire is out, it is no longer shining or burning.
dictionaryExamples: When we got home, all the lights were out.
Is that fire completely out?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I looked out through the window to check if the lights were out in the windows of the block of flats next to ours. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a long distance away from land, a town or your own country
dictionaryExamples: The fishing boats were out at sea for three days.
They live out in the country, miles from anywhere.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today I live out in the country. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romansch

sense.def: having no money, no luck and no opportunities
dictionaryExamples: Nobody loves you when you're down and out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The neglect of social security as a vital point in state policies leaves homeless people down and out, with little chance for improving their bleak prospects. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

blocks.phrase: the ins and outs of sth

sense.def: the details of a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: the ins and outs of the legal system
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I knew all the ins and outs of every story but I couldn't stay one single day in bed without reading it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If the jury is (still) out on a subject, people do not yet know the answer or have a definite opinion about it.
dictionaryExamples: The jury's still out on whether these vitamins protect against cancer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that the jury is still out on the effects of television and other media. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

blocks.phrase: go out of your way to do sth

sense.def: to try very hard to do something pleasant for someone
dictionaryExamples: He went out of his way to make us feel welcome.

blocks.phrase: get/have sth out of the way

sense.def: to finish a task or to get rid of something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: I'll go shopping when I've got this essay out of the way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a joyful reunion and everybody was grateful to have all misunderstandings out of the way and to be one big family once more. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: when something unpleasant and difficult to control starts, such as a war or disease
dictionaryExamples: an outbreak of flu/disease
the outbreak of war
Missouri saw several tornado outbreaks and a huge wind storm that hit St. Louis.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being a GP during the time of another outbreak of the flu, meant long hours of hard work. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the final result of an activity or process
dictionaryExamples: It's too early to predict the outcome of the meeting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In order to ensure a pleasant end-of-term activity and to avoid yet another negative outcome, it is necessary for us to dispose of a great sum of money. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: happening, used, or in a place that is outside and not inside a building
dictionaryExamples: an outdoor pool/concert
outdoor clothes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The water temperature of the outdoor pool is relatively cold because it's filled with natural mountain-spring-water. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: outside
dictionaryExamples: If the weather's good, we'll eat outdoors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My parents always tell me that I should spend more time outdoors. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: on the edge or surface of something
dictionaryExamples: Remove the outer layers of the onion.
I was asked to wait in an outer office.
They moved to the outer suburbs and have a long commute into the city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Perhaps you could give some consideration to the outer building, like renovation work. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: Someone who is outgoing is friendly, talks a lot, and enjoys meeting people.
dictionaryExamples: Anne is very outgoing, but her sister's quite shy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is very outgoing, friendly and communicative. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: going to another place, or leaving a job
dictionaryExamples: outgoing mail/calls/flights
the outgoing chairman
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We therefore propose you scrap your plans for Terminal 5 and instead try to reduce the number of incoming and outgoing flights, by diverting some planes to Luton or Stansted or Gatwick Airport. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a store at which a company sells its products at lower prices than usual
dictionaryExamples: a factory outlet
an outlet store
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people can only afford the local two dollar shop or factory outlets. International English Language Testing System; C1; Singhalese

sense.def: a place a plug fits in to connect a piece of electrical equipment to the electricity supply
dictionaryExamples: an electrical outlet

sense.def: a store or restaurant that sells products  of a particular company or a particular type
dictionaryExamples: The company has more than 1200 retail outlets nationwide.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, the atmosphere is cheered up by the presence of the most well-known fast-food outlets of our country, where the client can find some rest and food at a good [price]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a way for someone to express an emotion, idea, or ability
dictionaryExamples: She needs a job that will provide an outlet for her creative talent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am a very busy person but I try to find time to go to concerts, which, I think, are an excellent outlet for our feelings. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a short description of the most important ideas or facts about something
dictionaryExamples: If you read the minutes of the meeting, they'll give you a brief/broad outline of what was discussed.
Some novelists start by writing an outline.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Perhaps a brief outline of the party will help you to make your decision. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the shape made by the outside edge of something
dictionaryExamples: She drew the outline of the boat and then colored it in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The roof tiles were of a beautiful shade of pink, each of them carved in an outline of a heart. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to describe only the most important ideas or facts about something
dictionaryExamples: At the interview she outlined what I would be doing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I will briefly outline some personal details. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the likely future situation
dictionaryExamples: The economic outlook is good.
They were discussing the outlook for on-line retailers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The outlook for all three companies is bright over the next 5 years. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: the way a person thinks about something
dictionaryExamples: a positive/negative/optimistic outlook
Despite her illness, she has a great outlook on life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was a kind and friendly man, with an optimistic outlook on life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to be larger in number than another group
dictionaryExamples: Women outnumber men in our language classes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An annual average rate of 10% GDP growth for the past ten years has created more than 7 million new jobs, which outnumbered the number of new male entrants. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: no longer in a particular place or area
dictionaryExamples: He has been out of the country for a long time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you arrive please come to my home and then we can go there because it's out of the city. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: used to show movement away from the inside of a place or container
dictionaryExamples: A peach rolled out of the bag.
I jumped out of bed and ran downstairs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Once he told me that he and his other friend saw a cat falling out of a window. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: used to show what something is made from
dictionaryExamples: The dress is made out of silk.
The statue was carved out of a single block of stone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like wearing skirts made out of denim because they fit me perfectly. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: from among an amount or number
dictionaryExamples: Nine out of ten people said they liked the product.
No one got 20 out of 20  in the test.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He got 99.4 out of 100, "Oh my God". Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: old and no longer useful, correct or fashionable
dictionaryExamples: These unemployment figures are out of date.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, the information in the book seems out of date and mislead[ing]. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: If a machine or system is out of order, it is not working as it should.
dictionaryExamples: The elevator is out of order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last week my TV was out of order. Preliminary English Test; B1; Dutch

sense.def: not in a job
dictionaryExamples: I've been out of work for the last six months.
Both she and her husband are out of work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Right now I am out of work and would like to try som[e]thing different for a while. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: no longer in a particular condition or situation
dictionaryExamples: The patient is now out of danger.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She told me that D was out of danger and that she will have other information tomorrow. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: used to show the reason why someone does something
dictionaryExamples: I took the job out of necessity because we had no money left.
She volunteered out of a sense of duty.
I only went there out of curiosity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the warrior had left, the explorer [explored the cave] out of curiosity and [to] his big surprise found the treasure. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to have no more of something left
dictionaryExamples: We're almost out of gas.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By then I was out of money so I start[ed] walking. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to be breathing quickly because you have been running, walking fast, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He ran into the room, red-faced and out of breath.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although I was out of breath I started to run faster and faster. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: If something or someone is out of control, you cannot influence, limit or direct it.
dictionaryExamples: The weeds in my garden are out of control.
The car went out of control, crashing into an oncoming truck.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had just driven through Piazza Duomo, when another car came round a corner much too fast, skidded, and went out of control. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: If someone or something appears out of nowhere, it appears suddenly or unexpectedly.
dictionaryExamples: The car came out of nowhere and we had to swerve to miss it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was lying all alone on the beach, then suddenly, out of nowhere, right behind me those strange creatures appeared. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to not do something well because you have not done it recently
dictionaryExamples: I didn't play very well today - I'm out of practice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think playing in the club will be a great opportunity for me so as not to be out of practice. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: not available in a store
dictionaryExamples: The book is out of stock at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And sometimes the item you are looking for is out of stock. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: If vegetables or fruit are out of season, they are not usually available at that time.
dictionaryExamples: Strawberries are out of season now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As our place was famous for fresh sea food, I bought crabs and salmon although they were out of season and expensive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: singing or playing the wrong notes
dictionaryExamples: The piano is out of tune.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even if you sing out of tune please call us. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: If something happens out of the blue, it is completely unexpected.
dictionaryExamples: An old fried of mine from college called me out of the blue yesterday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Kim, I was extremely happy when I received your letter out of the blue. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: not having the knowledge, experience, or skills to deal with a particular subject or situation
dictionaryExamples: When they start talking about philosophy, I'm completely out of my depth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was my first day of school. What I can remember is that I really felt out of my depth: my parents were so happy that I couldn't succeed in telling them that I was terribly frightened and that [the only] thing that I wanted was my doll. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: unusual or different
dictionaryExamples: The investigation revealed nothing out of the ordinary.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This event is something out of the ordinary for local life and it gives our town prestige and originality. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be of extremely good quality
dictionaryExamples: Their chocolate cake is just out of this world!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The dessert trays are out of this world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: If someone's actions or words are out of line, they are beyond what is considered acceptable in that situation.
dictionaryExamples: You can disagree with her, but calling her dishonest was way out of line.
