sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today I see that my mother was right in this aspect since I acted extremely out of line sometimes and a soft hand certainly wouldn't help me in the future. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to become difficult to control
dictionaryExamples: It was the end of week and the children were getting a little out of hand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A few solutions can prevent this problem from getting out of hand. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: not in the correct position
dictionaryExamples: Why are my files all out of place?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was awful getting back from school and se[e]ing all my things out of place. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: not right or suitable for a particular situation
dictionaryExamples: Everyone else was wearing jeans and I felt completely out of place in my office clothes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This does not mean everybody is wearing tuxedos and dresses but you might be out of place just wearing shorts and a shirt. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: If something is out of proportion, it is much bigger or smaller than it should be, when compared to other things.
dictionaryExamples: The punishment is completely out of proportion to the crime.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you were doing it to make a profit, I could understand, but for a library it is just out of proportion [and] I even believe more people could be attracted [if] the prices decrease. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: If something is out of the question, it is not possible or not allowed.
dictionaryExamples: Providing more money is out of the question.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Walking home was out of the question since that would have taken even longer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: If you go somewhere out of season, you go during a period of the year when few people are there.
dictionaryExamples: I prefer to travel out of season.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some towns [that] are completely dependent on tourism "die" out of season, while others are destroyed because of the excessive emigration of [their] people. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: not healthy or physically strong
dictionaryExamples: Since I stopped riding my bike, I've gotten out of shape.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I no longer run and it has been more than a year since the last time I raced, [so] I am out of shape. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to be unaware of things that have been happening or what other people think
dictionaryExamples: Tell me what's been going on - I've been away for a month and out of touch.
A few of the older teachers are completely out of touch with their students.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In much worse cases, some individuals may even be trapped in the virtual world and get out of touch with the real one. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: old and no longer useful, correct or fashionable
dictionaryExamples: I had a very out-of-date map.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't want to be an out-of-date person. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: an amount of something produced by a person, machine, factory, country, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Last year British manufacturing output fell by 14%.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The right-wing thinkers claim that unemployment is one of the indicators in [the] economy, displaying [a] lack of balance between industrial output and citizens' demands. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a strong feeling of anger or shock
dictionaryExamples: Many politicians and members of the public expressed outrage at the verdict.

sense.def: something that causes great anger or shock
dictionaryExamples: The terrible living conditions of migrant workers, he said, were an outrage.
It's an outrage  that so much public money should have been wasted in this way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It shows one child's reaction to the outrage, to the fear and it as been held out as an example of the unthinkable and cruel effects that a racist mentality may have. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to cause someone to feel very angry, shocked, or upset
dictionaryExamples: The proposed pay cut outraged the staff.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was outraged when I was given a copy of an article published in your magazine. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: shocking or extreme
dictionaryExamples: outrageous behavior/clothes
That's an outrageous thing to say!
They're charging an outrageous amount of money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The only negative thing to be said about [this restaurant] is that the prices are outrageous, but [it is] worth every penny. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: not inside a building
dictionaryExamples: It's cold outside!
Why don't you go outside and play for a little while?
Should we eat outside as long as the weather is so nice?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can sit on the chair outside and look [at the] bridge. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: not in a particular room or building but near it
dictionaryExamples: I'll wait outside while you get changed.
She knocked on his door of his room and left the tray outside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are going to go to Top Totty and [will] wait for you outside. Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese

sense.def: not in a particular room, building, or place, but near it
dictionaryExamples: She waited outside his room for nearly two hours.
He lives just outside Birmingham.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll meet you outside the art class. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: not in a building
dictionaryExamples: an outside light
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was going to say to him to turn on the outside light, but seeing his face, I changed my mind. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: coming from another place or organization
dictionaryExamples: The company has called in outside experts.

sense.def: the outer part or side of something
dictionaryExamples: The outside of the house needs to be painted.
The house is much bigger than it looked from the outside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It had been dark in the room since the door was locked from the outside. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: the outer area of a city or town
dictionaryExamples: The new assembly plant is being built on the outskirts of town.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There I booked a room in a small lovely boarding house in the outskirts of the town. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: excellent and much better than most
dictionaryExamples: an outstanding achievement
It's an area of outstanding natural beauty.
This is an outstanding first novel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although it was an outstanding festival, I would like to point out some problems [that] happened there. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to be greater or more important than something else
dictionaryExamples: The benefits of this treatment far outweigh the risks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, in my opinion the advantages far outweigh the disadvantages and competition is a natural phenomenon that we should accept.  International English Language Testing System; C1; Kurdish

sense.def: in the shape of an egg or a slightly flat circle
dictionaryExamples: an oval mirror
an oval face
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was green, oval and opaque. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a boxlike part of a stove or separate device with a door, which is used to cook food
dictionaryExamples: a toaster/microwave oven
a warm/hot oven
Pour the cake batter into  the pan, place it  in the oven, and bake at 350° for 30 minutes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They eat the traditional food - souvlaki and potatoes [cooked] in the oven. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: more than a particular amount, number, or age
dictionaryExamples: Most of the bikes cost/are over $500.
Children over the age of 12  pay full-price.
They are already $25 million over budget.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have to dance in a school and over two hundred people [will watch] us. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: covering something or someone
dictionaryExamples: Put a blanket over you to keep warm.
I put my hands over my eyes because I didn't want to see.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Wear an apron over your clothes. Key English Test; A2; Hindi

sense.def: above or higher than something
dictionaryExamples: The sign over the door said "Exit."
A flock of geese flew over the lake.
She held the umbrella over both of us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides that, you have voted for the construction of a new bridge over the main street. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: across from one side of something to the other, especially by going up and then down
dictionaryExamples: She jumped over the gate.
The road goes over the mountains.
She often chats with her neighbor over the fence.
From the top of the tower you could see for miles over the city.
When we get over the bridge we'll stop for gas.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I most enjoyed [it] when we [were] cycling over the hills, because there weren't any people and it was peaceful and qui[et]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: everywhere in a particular place
dictionaryExamples: Soon the news was all over town.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The people in the class are from all over the world. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: during a particular period of time
dictionaryExamples: I was in Seattle over the summer.
We discussed the plans over lunch.
It's fascinating to watch how a baby changes and develops over time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could [make] up for the work I missed over the weekend, if that's alright with you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: on the other side of
dictionaryExamples: Their house is just over the river.

sense.def: in this/that place
dictionaryExamples: Put your bags down over there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How is everything over there? Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: using
dictionaryExamples: They spoke over the phone.
I often listen to radio over the Internet these days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She laughed over the phone, and said "It's really like you". First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: in control of or teaching someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Parents want to have control over their children.
She's a sales manager but she has a regional sales director over  her.
The victory over the French at Waterloo was Wellington's greatest triumph.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fortunately, my parents do not wield authority over me and my siblings like dictators. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: connected with or about
dictionaryExamples: It's stupid arguing over something so trivial.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The teams themselves suffered from these money problems: recently strikes broke out in basketball teams in the U.S. when players began to argue over money. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: more than a particular amount or level
dictionaryExamples: People who are 65 years old and over can get half-price tickets.

sense.def: from one side or place to another
dictionaryExamples: She leaned over and kissed me.
Why don't you come over  for dinner on Thursday?
We're having friends over for a barbecue..
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He came over to me and we talked a while. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: finished
dictionaryExamples: I'll be glad when the semester is over.
The show was over before nine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: David smiled triumphantly and said, "It is all over!" First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: describes the way an object moves or is moved so that a different part of it is facing up
dictionaryExamples: She turned another page over.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A big truck had turned over and blocked the road and there was no other way for us to go, so we had to wait. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: happening or done many times
dictionaryExamples: I read the article over and over.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've been searching in newspapers over and over again and finally after a couple of days I found something. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: repeated from the beginning
dictionaryExamples: We had to start all over again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that I went back to my home in Ribeirao Preto to begin my routine all over again. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to do something difficult or unpleasant  as soon as you can so that you do not have to worry about it any more
dictionaryExamples: I got all my apologies over and done with at the beginning of the meeting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not to mention that he knew that he had to get his degree over and done with before he started making serious decisions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: in general rather than in particular, or including all the people or things in a particular group or situation
dictionaryExamples: The overall situation is good, despite a few minor problems.
Overall, it has been a good year.
The overall winner, after ten games, will receive $50,000.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Overall these two restaurants are worth [going] to for nice meals. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: over the side of a boat and into the water
dictionaryExamples: Wait! Something fell overboard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My diary is lost - it fell overboard on my way home. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to do something too much, or to be too excited about something
dictionaryExamples: I think I went overboard cooking this dinner – there is enough to feed a dozen people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While no one should restrict their eating habits to the point eating is no longer a pleasure, but rather a chore, it is important not to go overboard, completely disregarding the advice of nutrition experts. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to deal with and control a problem or feeling
dictionaryExamples: I admire the way she has overcome her difficulties/problems and made a success of her life.
Eventually he managed to overcome his shyness in class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Trying to overcome my fear, I was slowly going toward the dangerous stranger. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to suddenly have too much of  a feeling
dictionaryExamples: She was overcome by emotion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When she got in her house she was overcome by a sense of wrath and started screaming and crying. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: containing too many people or things
dictionaryExamples: an overcrowded classroom/prison
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you arrive about midday, the trams are likely to be overcrowded.Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to do or use too much of something
dictionaryExamples: I went to the gym yesterday, but I think I overdid it a bit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, people usually overdo it and prefer making use of the modern technology to meeting a friend. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: If you are overdrawn, you have taken more money out of your bank account than you had in it.
dictionaryExamples: Your account is overdrawn.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In other words their expenditure [is] much more than their income. They get into debt and [are] mostly overdrawn. International English Language Testing System; C1; Turkish

sense.def: to guess or think that something is or will be bigger or better than it really is
dictionaryExamples: They overestimated her ability to do the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In spite of the progress achieved in promoting the social status of women, one should not overestimate the significance of these achievements to ordinary women's careers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: If a container overflows, the things inside it start to come out because it is too full, and if the contents of a container overflow, they come out because it is too full.
dictionaryExamples: The sink overflowed, and there's water all over the floor!
The river overflowed its banks after the heavy rainfall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a result of relentless rain the river had broken its banks and overflowed violently. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: If a place is overflowing, there are too many people in it.
dictionaryExamples: The square was overflowing with people trying to see the queen.
The train platform was overflowing with passengers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The prisons are overflowing, society is losing out in many ways. International English Language Testing System; C2; German

sense.def: to have a lot of a quality or emotion
dictionaryExamples: Her father was overflowing with pride as he watched her receive her award.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She felt overflowing with indignation as if he had been rude to her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to hear what someone is saying when they are not talking to you
dictionaryExamples: I overheard him telling her he was leaving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I once overheard a remark from a person who had just been in Italy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Norwegian

sense.def: If two subjects or activities overlap, they are the same in some way.
dictionaryExamples: Although our job titles are different, our responsibilities overlap quite a lot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, these two motivations can be overlapping and ideally they do overlap. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to fill something with too much or more then it should contain
dictionaryExamples: Don’t overload the washer or it won’t work properly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly the buses and trains are mostly overloaded. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: to give someone too much to do
dictionaryExamples: All the staff are completely overloaded.
I can’t go out tonight – I’m overloaded with work
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was also overloaded with work and had many doubts about joining the group at all. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: when someone has more of something than they can deal with
dictionaryExamples: We are suffering from data overload here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Will we get to the point of "information overload"? International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans

sense.def: to have a view of something from above
dictionaryExamples: Our hotel room overlooked the harbor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had a delicious lunch in a c[oz]y restaurant overlooking the Cote d'Azur. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to not notice or consider something
dictionaryExamples: His film was nominated for an Oscar, but Reiner himself was overlooked as best director.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, man's basic needs cannot be overlooked and a certain amount of wealth can be put to very good use, wisely to provide for oneself and one's family and home. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: for or during the night
dictionaryExamples: an overnight stop in Paris
You can stay overnight if you want to.
Don't forget to pack an overnight bag.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We will stay in our tents overnight and [get] up early in the morning to reach the next camping site. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: very quickly or suddenly
dictionaryExamples: Change does not happen overnight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am aware of the fact that it is not at all an easy path nor  is [it] something that can happen overnight. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: in, from or to other countries
dictionaryExamples: We need to open up the overseas markets.
There are a lot of overseas students in Cambridge.
Many more people work overseas these days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is suggested that one of our English as a Foreign Language lessons should be filmed, as there are some 100 overseas students who are from over 30 countries in our school. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to go past a vehicle or person that is going in the same direction
dictionaryExamples: We were overtaken by a red sports car.
She overtook the leader in the last seconds of the race to win the gold medal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course it is easier [for a bike] to overtake the cars in traffic jams. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to go past something by being a greater amount or degree
dictionaryExamples: US sales have been overtaken by sales in Europe.
We planned to hold a meeting tomorrow, but events have overtaken us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This however was projected to be overtaken by people coming from the 35-49 year old bracket by 2006. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: extra time that you work after your usual working hours
dictionaryExamples: He's been working a lot of overtime lately.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can't go on living like this, chasing around and always being press[ur]ed by your work and all this overtime. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a short description giving the most important facts about something
dictionaryExamples: I'll just give you an overview of the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, I would recommend a student and a teacher to be interviewed, so that we can provide a better overview of the institution itself, with both the opinions of those who teach and those who learn here. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: knowledge of the general features of something
dictionaryExamples: Having spent some time there, she had a good overview of the market.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As my main interest was to get an overview of the current market situation, I was simply impressed by the variety of companies that you've presented. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: too heavy or too fat
dictionaryExamples: He's still a few pounds overweight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In England the majority of people are either overweight or underweight. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: If a feeling or situation overwhelms someone, it has an effect that is too strong or extreme.
dictionaryExamples: She was overwhelmed by the excitement of it all.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am sure the students from the acting classes will be overwhelmed by the grandeur of the 200-seat theat[er]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: very strong in effect or large in amount
dictionaryExamples: She felt an overwhelming urge/desire/need to tell someone about what had happened.
An overwhelming majority voted in favor of the proposal.
I felt an overwhelming sense of relief when the semester was over.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Second, the overwhelming majority of your staff members speaks English only, which poses a big problem for those passengers who can not speak English. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: Someone who is overworked has to work too much.
dictionaryExamples: We're overworked and underpaid.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People are overworked and often choose fast food for dinner. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to have to pay money back to someone
dictionaryExamples: I owe Janet ten dollars.
We still owe money on our mortgage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please tell me how much I owe you for that. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to have to give something to someone because they deserve it
dictionaryExamples: I think you owe  me an explanation/apology.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I owe you a favor. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

blocks.phrase: owe your existence/success, etc., to sb/sth

sense.def: to have something or achieve something because of someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: The museum owes much of its success to the present generation of young artists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many restaurants, bars and gift shops owe their existence to the fact that visitors to our country enjoy the view of the river and its surroundings. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: because of
dictionaryExamples: The concert has been cancelled owing to low ticket sales.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To start with, [it] is a great idea to change rooms because the[y] are too crowded, owing to the fact that there a lot of people. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a bird with a flat face, large eyes, and strong curved nails, which hunts small mammals at night
dictionaryExamples: We heard an owl hooting in the night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could hear a[n] owl hooting in the tree nearby. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: belonging to or done by a particular person or thing
dictionaryExamples: All of the students have their own dictionaries.
She has her own apartment.
She makes all her own clothes.
I'm going to be out tonight, so you'll have to get your own dinner.
Was that your own idea or did someone suggest it to you?
"Is that your mom's car?" "No, it's my own."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have to bring our own paints. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: belonging to someone or something
dictionaryExamples: I'll have a home of my own someday.
He wanted an apartment of his own.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also bought a cupboard of my own, so that I need not share with my sister. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: alone
dictionaryExamples: I like living on my own.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On Wedn[e]sday morning I went on my own to see [the] Vatican. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: without any help
dictionaryExamples: Ryan can't get into his shirt on his own - he's just a baby!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe I can do the missing work on my own. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to be as successful as other people or things
dictionaryExamples: Alison could always hold her own in political debates.

sense.def: to have something that legally belongs to you
dictionaryExamples: We own our house.
I've never owned a suit in my life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is owned by a Japanese owner. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: someone who owns something
dictionaryExamples: Are you the owner of this car?
We still haven't found the dog's owner.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The owner was an old woman who lives alone in a big house with her pet animals. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: when you own something
dictionaryExamples: Do you have any proof of ownership for this car?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Converting all of this into private ownership is a long term process. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a gas that is in the air and that animals need to live
dictionaryExamples: an oxygen tank
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everybody needs oxygen and trees produce oxygen. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a form of oxygen that exists high in the atmosphere
dictionaryExamples: the ozone layer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is probably no child who hasn't heard about the holes in the ozone layer or the greenhouse effect. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish
